[[Suheil Al Hassan]]{{cite web|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/exclusive-tiger-forces-reportedly-redeployed-aleppo-front/|title= Exclusive: Tiger Forces Reportedly Redeployed to Aleppo Front |publisher=Al Masdar|date= |accessdate=22 February 2015}}{{cite web|author=Edward Dark Columnist  |url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2014/02/barrel-bombing-syria-aleppo-rebels-regime-war.html# |title=Barrel bombings cause mass evacuation in east Aleppo |publisher=Al-monitor|date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} |units1 = {{flagicon|Syria|1932}} [[Free Syrian Army]]: *Jaysh Mohammad Brigade{{cite web|url=http://www.pukmedia.com/EN/EN_Direje.aspx?Jimare=15762 |title=ISIS and al-Nusra reportedly lose their final presence in Reef Ras al-A’in: al-Hasaka |publisher=Pukmedia.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} *[[Harakat Nour al-Din al-Zenki]] |units2 = {{flagicon image|Flag of the Syrian Arab Army.svg}} [[Syrian Army]]: *[[File:Syrian Republican Guard Symbol.svg|16px]] [[Republican Guard (Syria)|Republican Guard]] *[[Tiger Forces]] *[[Desert Hawks Brigade]] Pro-government militias * {{flagicon image|InfoboxNDF.png}} [[National Defence Forces (Syria)|National Defence Forces]] * {{flagicon image|Flag of the Ba'ath Party.svg}} [[Ba'ath Brigades]]{{cite web|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2014/03/syria-aleppo-sunni-quds-baath-brigades.html#|title=Pro-regime Sunni fighters in Aleppo defy sectarian narrative|work=Al-Monitor|accessdate=25 October 2014}} * [[File:Emblem of Liwa Al-Quds.svg|18px]] [[Liwa Al-Quds]] * [[Baqir Brigade]] {{small|(claimed)}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.aymennjawad.org/18859/the-local-defence-forces-regime-auxiliary-forces |title=The Local Defence Forces: Regime Auxiliary Forces in Aleppo |author=Aymenn Jawad Al-Tamimi |work= |date=23 May 2016 |accessdate=20 February 2018}} |strength1 = |strength2 = |casualties1 = |casualties2 = |casualties3 = 2,500+ civilians and rebels killed due to [[barrel bomb]]s (December 2013–May 2014)
203 civilians killed due to rebel hell cannon fire (July–December 2014){{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/12/12/us-mideast-crisis-attacks-idUSKBN0JQ17I20141212|title=Syrian rebel 'hell cannons' kill 300 civilians: monitoring group|work=Reuters|accessdate=15 December 2014}} |campaignbox = {{Campaignbox Battle of Aleppo}} }} '''Operation Canopus Star'''{{cite web|url=http://www.syrianperspective.com/2013/12/first-post-december-9-2013-al-nabak-liberated-jihadist-terrorists-crushed-in-damascus-terrorist-leader-killed-in-east-ghouta-by-saa-massive-operation-canopus-star-grinds-rats-in.html|title=AL-NABAK LIBERATED!!; JIHADIST TERRORISTS CRUSHED IN DAMASCUS; TERRORIST LEADER KILLED IN EAST GHOUTA BY SAA; MASSIVE OPERATION "CANOPUS STAR" GRINDS RATS IN ALEPPO; NEWS AND COMMENTARY; WILE E. COYOTE MOMENT|author=Ziad Fadel|date=9 December 2013|work=Syrian Perspective|accessdate=25 October 2014}} ({{lang-ar|عملية نجم سهيل}}) was an operation launched by the [[Syrian Army]], supported by [[Hezbollah]] and other allied militias, during the [[Syrian Civil War]], following [[Aleppo offensive (October–December 2013)|a successful offensive]] which re-established the military's supply route between Aleppo and central Syria. The aim of the operation was to encircle Aleppo and cut rebel supply lines into the city, thus besieging rebel-held areas. == The operation == === Aleppo air blitz === On 7 December 2013, an [[Airstrike|air raid]] on the town of Bezaa killed at least 20 people, including eight children and nine women.{{cite web|author=Thomson Reuters Foundation |url=http://www.trust.org/item/20131207144956-kvo2s/?source=hptop |title=Syrian Islamists seize Western-backed rebel bases -monitoring group |publisher=Trust.org |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} Between 15 and 28 December, a series of Army helicopter attacks with barrel bombs{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2013/Dec-19/241680-syria-extends-air-campaign-on-aleppo-region-activists.ashx#axzz2nv9rWutS |title=Syria extends air campaign on Aleppo region: activists |publisher=Dailystar.com.lb |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} against rebel-held areas of Aleppo left 517 people dead, including 151 children, 46 women and 46 rebels, according to the [[Syrian Observatory for Human Rights|SOHR]].{{cite web|url=http://www.enca.com/world/517-dead-fortnight-regime-strike-syria |title=517 dead in fortnight of regime strike in Syria |publisher=Enca.com |date=2013-12-29 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} 76 of those killed died on the first day alone,{{cite web|url=http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=658197 |title=Syria bomb raids on Aleppo 'kill 135' |publisher=Maannews.net |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} while 93–100 people were killed on 22 December.{{cite web|url=http://www.therecord.com/news-story/4286400-regime-s-barrel-bombs-bring-death-terror-to-syrian-city/ |title=Regime’s ‘barrel bombs’ bring death, terror to Syrian city |publisher=Therecord.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} By 18 December, 879 people were wounded.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/ap/2013-12-18/syrian-planes-pound-aleppo-for-fourth-straight-day#p1 |title=Syrian air raids exact high toll on Aleppo |publisher=Businessweek.com |date=2013-12-18 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} During the first four days the attacks were concentrated on Aleppo city, but on 19 December, the helicopter strikes were expanded to include surrounding villages.{{cite web|url=http://www.arabnews.com/news/495221 |title=Syria extends air campaign on Aleppo region: activists |publisher=Arabnews.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} A rebel commander claimed that by 26 December, more than 1,000 people had been killed in the bombing campaign.{{cite web |last=Kocaman |first=Aylin |url=http://www.aawsat.net/2013/12/article55325898 |title=Syria: Intense Aleppo offensive prompts mass exodus |publisher=Aawsat.net |date=2013-12-26 |accessdate=2014-05-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150128061147/http://www.aawsat.net/2013/12/article55325898 |archivedate=2015-01-28 |df= }} By the end of 6 January, the death toll in the bombings had risen to 603, including 172 children, 54 women and 52 rebels.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=472034219571588&set=a.150495128392167.28686.121855461256134&type=1 |title=Regime kills more than 600 people, including 225 children and women, in three weeks of barrel bombs and airstrikes on Aleppo |publisher=Facebook.com |date=2013-12-15 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} On 9 January, aid groups stated more than 700 people had been killed since the start of the bombing campaign.{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/jihadists-fighting-back-6248 |title=Jihadists fighting back |publisher=Thedailystar.net |date=2014-01-10 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} On 25 December, pro-government sources claimed that the Syrian Army captured the al-Jbanat area near Aleppo's al-Sheikh Maqsoud neighbourhood.{{cite web|url=http://breakingnews.sy/en/article/31225.html |title=The Army retakes al-Sheikh Maqsoud and al-Jbanat area of Aleppo |publisher=Breakingnews.sy |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} === Eastern Aleppo battles === [[File:2alep.png|thumb|left|Map of the offensive]] On 11 January 2014, government forces secured the area of al-Naqqarin and Sheikh Yusuf hill{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/index.php?option=com_news&nid=13676&Itemid=2&task=displaynews#.UtGV2fRDufU |title=URGENT :: system controls the area in Aleppo |publisher=Syriahr.com |date=2014-01-11 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} and were advancing towards the industrial area of Aleppo city.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Jan-11/243797-syria-jihadists-kill-5-rebels-in-bombing-activists.ashx#axzz2q6bl5600 |title=Syrian troops advance on Aleppo area: activists |publisher=Dailystar.com.lb |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} According to opposition activists, the rebels were in fear of losing the industrial district, which would cut their supply lines from [[Turkey]]. The next day, the Army also advanced towards the highway linking the airport to the government-held western part of the city.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/01/syrian-troops-push-towards-aleppo-area-2014112105719722237.html |title=Syrian troops push towards Aleppo city |publisher=Aljazeera.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} On 14 January, the Army reportedly captured al-Zarzour, al-Taaneh, al-Subeihieh and Height 53 on the eastern outskirts of Aleppo.{{cite web|last=Dagher |first=Sam |url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702303819704579318732940300704 |title=Fighting Among Rebels Boosts Syrian Regime |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=2014-01-13 |accessdate=2014-05-29}}{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/world/syrian-army-recaptures-five-towns-near-aleppo-s-airport_903928.html |title=Syrian army recaptures five towns near Aleppo's airport |publisher=Zeenews.india.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} On 15 January, an Al-Manar correspondent reported that the Army captured al-Sabaheyya, al-Faory and Tal-Riman, east of Al-Safira,{{cite web|url=http://www.almanar.com.lb/english/adetails.php?fromval=1&cid=23&frid=23&eid=129985 |title=Syrian Army Advances Eastern Aleppo, Eliminates Terrorists in Several Provinces |publisher=Almanar.com.lb |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} and was pushing towards the electricity station, northeast of Al-Safira.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/syriahroe/posts/475550169219993?stream_ref=10 |title=Aleppo province |publisher=Facebook.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} Later, Al-Manar claimed that the Army captured Tall Alam and Huwejna, east of Aleppo, also on the approaches to the electricity station.{{cite web|url=http://www.almanar.com.lb/english/adetails.php?eid=130194&frid=23&seccatid=20&cid=23&fromval=1 |title=ISIL Controls Raqa, Kills Tawheed’ Commander in Aleppo |publisher=Almanar.com.lb |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} At the same time, government troops pushed out of [[Kuweires Military Airbase|Kweires military airport]], east of Aleppo and the station, and captured villages around the base.{{cite web|author=Edward Dark Columnist  |url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2014/01/islamic-front-isis-rebel-clashes-syria.html |title=Islamic Front no answer for Syria conflict |publisher=Al-monitor.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} On 17 January, the Army bombarded the villages of Tal-Na'am, Jobul and Tal-Estabel and captured the village of Tal-Sobeha.{{cite web |url=http://halabnews.com/news/46426 |title=System Controls The "Hill Sbihia" And The Bombing Of Braszmat Missiles Targeting The Villages Of Rural Southern |publisher=Halabnews.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140118022116/http://halabnews.com/news/46426 |archivedate=2014-01-18 |df= }} By 18 January, it was confirmed government troops captured the town of Tall Alam, just west of the power plant. Sheikh Zayat, on the southern outskirts of the industrial zone, was also captured.{{cite web|url=https://fbcdn-sphotos-h-a.akamaihd.net/hphotos-ak-prn2/t1/q72/s720x720/1551540_476645092445916_474672971_n.jpg|title=the Rebellion Losing Ground as ISIS and Loyalists Are Advancing Together|publisher=|date=|accessdate=2014-05-29|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201234215/https://fbcdn-sphotos-h-a.akamaihd.net/hphotos-ak-prn2/t1/q72/s720x720/1551540_476645092445916_474672971_n.jpg|archivedate=2014-02-01|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://i0.wp.com/www.syrianperspective.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/image_1.jpg |accessdate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150128055543/http://i0.wp.com/www.syrianperspective.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/image_1.jpg |archivedate=January 28, 2015 }} On 21 January, clashes took place around the village of Balat, accompanied by an air raid on the village.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/syriahroe/posts/478087808966229?stream_ref=10 |title=Aleppo province |publisher=Facebook.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} On 22 January, the Army made an attempt to advance on the central [[Aziziyeh]] district of Aleppo city.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Jan-22/244940-syria-missile-attack-kills-10-as-peace-talks-open.ashx#axzz2oNa3sbT8 |title=Syria missile attack kills 10 as peace talks open |publisher=Dailystar.com.lb |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} At the same time, the town of Aziza, on the southern outskirts of Aleppo, came under rebel attack which was continuing as of 24 January.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Jan-24/245120-zawahri-urges-end-to-deadly-clashes-between-rebels-and-jihadists.ashx#axzz2rEUjd2s1 |title=Zawahri urges end to deadly clashes between rebels and jihadists |publisher=Dailystar.com.lb |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} On 25 January, the Army captured the neighborhood of Karam Al Qasr on the eastern side of Aleppo city, after three days of fighting.{{cite web|url=http://live.aljazeera.com/Event/Syria_Live_Blog/103108577 |title=Syria Live Blog |publisher=Live.aljazeera.com |date=2014-01-25 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} On 27 January, fighting was renewed in the area of the [[Umayyad Mosque]] in Aleppo's Old City, as the rebels claimed of destroying a Hezbollah base at Mount Hoihna and capturing most of the buildings in the town Maarath Al-Artik, on Aleppo's northwest outskirts.{{cite web |url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/16419719-syria-opposition-advancing-in-aleppo-taking-positions-both-from-assad-and-jihadists |title=Syria: Opposition Advancing In Aleppo Taking Positions Both From Assad And Jihadists: |publisher=Allvoices.com |date=2014-01-27 |accessdate=2014-05-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203163601/http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/16419719-syria-opposition-advancing-in-aleppo-taking-positions-both-from-assad-and-jihadists |archivedate=2014-02-03 |df= }} On 28 January, rebels captured the Maarath Al-Artik mountain, which the Army used to shell nearby rebel-held towns.{{cite web|url=http://live.aljazeera.com/Event/Syria_Live_Blog/103573669 |title=Fighting in Aleppo as rebels seize Maaret Al-Arteq mountain |publisher=Live.aljazeera.com |date=2014-01-28 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} On the same day, the Army made more advances and seized the districts of Ballura and Kasr al-Tarrab, according to the pro-government al-Watan newspaper. It too said that an operation had been launched from Nairab airport in the east, as well as Aziza village in the south, while adding that troops had reached the outskirts of Mayssar, a rebel bastion in southeast Aleppo. At the same time, the SOHR confirmed the military captured the Karm al-Qasr district, on the southeastern edge of Aleppo, and reported that residents of Mayssar, Marjeh and Enzarrat districts were fleeing their homes for "neighbourhoods controlled by regime forces because of the fighting".{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Jan-28/245577-syria-army-edges-forward-in-aleppo.ashx#axzz2pkBJjgkD |title=Army makes first push toward Aleppo in a year |publisher=Dailystar.com.lb |date=2014-01-28 |accessdate=2014-05-29}}{{cite web|author=AFPTuesday, Jan 28, 2014 |url=http://news.asiaone.com/news/world/syria-army-edges-forward-aleppo |title=Syria army edges forward in Aleppo |publisher=News.asiaone.com |date=2014-01-28 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} During the month of January, government forces also pushed into the Old City district of Aleppo and captured the Farafra area.{{cite web|author=Edward Dark Columnist  |url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2014/03/syria-aleppo-sunni-quds-baath-brigades.html |title=Pro-regime Sunni fighters in Aleppo defy sectarian narrative |publisher=Al-monitor.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} On 2 February, the ''[[Al-Watan (Syria)|Al-Watan]]'' newspaper announced that the Army captured most of the eastern Karam al-Turab district of Aleppo.[https://web.archive.org/web/20140306114733/http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hBvcNkUAjh_byCdoCjGGh8FjNPqw?hl=en&docId=747d18ba-3c57-4c31-a2f7-4b8403d06832 Syrian forces step up deadly attacks on Aleppo] On 16 February, government forces captured the village of Sheikh Najjar, south of the industrial zone,{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/index.php?option=com_news&nid=15428&Itemid=2&task=displaynews#.UwISn_ldWfU |title=Progress of the Islamic state in the countryside of Aleppo |publisher=Syriahr.com |date=2014-02-17 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} as well as Talet al-Ghali, on the eastern outskirts of Aleppo.{{cite web|url=http://www.almanar.com.lb/english/adetails.php?eid=135925&cid=23&fromval=1&frid=23&seccatid=20&s1=1 |title=Syrian Army Tightens Grip on Yabroud, Regains Control over Several Areas |publisher=Almanar.com.lb |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}}{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/CdricLabrousse/status/438805532686561280/photo/1 |title=Twitter / CdricLabrousse: NEW CHRONICLE MAP - UPDATE |publisher=Twitter.com |date=2014-02-26 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} On 19 February, rebels claimed to had recaptured Sheikh Najjar, while, the [[SOHR]] stated it was unclear who controlled the area.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/Article.aspx?id=247776#axzz2oNa3sbT8 |title=Barrel bomb claims 18 lives near school in Deraa |publisher=Dailystar.com.lb |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} The next day, the Army re-secured Sheikh Najjar{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/index.php?option=com_news&nid=15545&Itemid=2&task=displaynews#.UwXdxfldWfV |title=Progress of the system perimeter of Aleppo |publisher=Syriahr.com |date=2014-02-19 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} and captured two strategic hills that overlook the eastern neighborhoods of Aleppo, al-Ghalia and Syriatel.{{cite web|url=http://english.al-akhbar.com/content/syrian-army-prepares-attack-its-southern-border |title=Syrian army prepares for an attack from its southern border |publisher=English.al-akhbar.com |date=2014-02-19 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} On 24 February, the Army made progress in the Sheikh Najjar industrial zone, with rebels sending reinforcements to the area. The military was attempting to capture strategic areas in Sheikh Najjar that overlook the outskirts of the Aleppo central prison, which had been under a rebel siege for over a year. The Army hoped to station artillery at those positions to help fend off attacks on the prison.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Feb-24/248342-syrian-troops-rebels-battle-for-key-aleppo-district.ashx#axzz2uFhSNi9e |title=Syrian troops, rebels battle for key Aleppo district |publisher=Dailystar.com.lb |date=2014-02-24 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} The next day, the military captured the factory of the [[Zanoubia]] ceramic company in the southern al-Sheikh Sa'id district of Aleppo. Soldiers, NDF militiamen and Hezbollah fighters also captured new positions near Base 80, putting them one kilometer from the Tariq al-Bab district.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Feb-26/248516-regime-forces-inch-closer-to-aleppo.ashx#axzz2uPx5ODI3 |title=Regime forces inch closer to Aleppo |publisher=Dailystar.com.lb |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}}{{cite web|url=http://www.syriahr.com/index.php?option=com_news&nid=15848&Itemid=2&task=displaynews#.UwzdbfldWfU |title=Tens of martyrs and wounded of the Phalange Islamic Fighting |publisher=Syriahr.com |date=2014-02-25 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} The area they captured included the districts of Talat Barkat and al-Ard al-Hamra.{{cite web|author=27.02.2014 |url=http://english.pravda.ru/opinion/columnists/27-02-2014/126947-saudis_qataris_chechens-0/ |title=Saudis, Qataris and Chechens liquidated in Syria |publisher=English.pravda.ru |date=2014-02-27 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} On 27 February, the military reportedly captured Brakat hill, reaching to the east of the al-Sakan al-Shababi area of Aleppo city.{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/2014/02/27/352540/syria-forces-continue-mopup-ops/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140228012153/http://www.presstv.ir/detail/2014/02/27/352540/syria-forces-continue-mopup-ops/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2014-02-28|title=Syria forces continue mop-up operations, kill 50 militants |publisher=Presstv.ir |date=2014-02-27 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} On 2 March, government forces captured the Majbal al-Zeft area near the Aleppo central prison,{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/syriahroe/posts/496093740498969?stream_ref=10 |title=Aleppo province 1 |publisher=Facebook.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} as well as the Al-Khaledia neighborhood of Aleppo city.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/syriahroe/posts/496145117160498?stream_ref=10 |title=Aleppo province 2 |publisher=Facebook.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} The next day, there were conflicting claims of the takeover of the Al-Majbal area with both the Army and the opposition claiming to be in control.{{cite web|url=http://english.farsnews.com/newstext.aspx?nn=13921212000581 |title=Syrian Army Breaks Siege of Aleppo Central Prison |publisher=English.farsnews.com |date=2014-03-03 |accessdate=2014-05-29}}{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/syriahroe/posts/496330110475332?stream_ref=10 |title=Aleppo province 3 |publisher=Facebook.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} The military also claimed to be on the verge of breaking the siege of the prison after capturing 60 percent of the industrial zone and surrounding the rebels in the area. At this time,{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/news/pages/1487cdb8-a34d-4300-b553-8c3abfcec1c3 |title=خسائر للنظام بحلب وحماة وتقدم بمحيط يبرود |publisher=Aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} rebels attempted to halt the Army advance on Aleppo's outskirts by attacking government-held villages south of the city, and thus trying to block the Army supply route (Aleppo-Khanaser-Hama). However, military reinforcements arrived to reinforce these positions and the attempted rebel advance was stopped.{{cite web|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/security/2014/03/syria-army-impose-blockade-militants-aleppo.html# |title=Syrian army to impose blockade in Aleppo |publisher=Al-monitor.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} On 9 March, fighting was once again raging around Al-Majbal hill, near the central prison.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/syriahroe/posts/498849400223403?stream_ref=10 |title=Aleppo province |publisher=Facebook.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} By this point, government forces had captured a strategic hill, where they positioned artillery to bombard rebel positions around the prison. === Final Army push to the prison === In early May, government forces captured the Al-Majbal area and the Breij roundabout, thus taking control of the northeastern entrance to Aleppo. This also brought government forces close to the central prison.{{cite web|url=http://www.syriahr.com/index.php?option=com_news&nid=18672&Itemid=2&task=displaynews#.U2P3uvmSyfU |title=System controls the entrance to the north-east of Aleppo |publisher=Syriahr.com |date=2014-05-02 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} The Army also reached the al-Kindi Hospital.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/EjmAlrai/status/462215030478745600 |title=Elijah J Magnier |publisher=Wayback.archive.org |date=2014-05-03 |accessdate=2014-05-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503113727/https://twitter.com/EjmAlrai/status/462215030478745600 |archivedate=May 3, 2014 }} Within a week, rebels made claims to had retaken several points in [[Bureij]],{{cite web|url=http://wikimapia.org/14394818/Bureij |title=Bureij |publisher=Wikimapia.org |date=2013-05-16 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} amid the arrival of hundreds of rebel reinforcements from Idlib, Hama and Aleppo provinces. According to the SOHR, 21 rebel fighters and 30 pro-government fighters were killed in the clashes, in addition to three disabled Army tanks.{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/index.php?option=com_news&nid=2228&Itemid=2&task=displaynews#.U2gRk_l_tCg |title=More than 60 fighters killed in Aleppo yesterday |publisher=Syriahr.com |date=2014-05-05 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} However, other opposition sources denied the claim saying rebel forces had made no progress in the Bureij area.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/TahrirSy/status/463219915466764288 |title=TahrirSy |publisher=Twitter.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}}{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/Alepponian/status/463214688281849856 |title=Alepponian |publisher=Twitter.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} Despite this, rebels managed to retake the al-Majbal area at the cost of at least 27 fighters, while the Army suffered several casualties.{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/index.php?option=com_news&nid=18936&Itemid=2&task=displaynews#.U21Snvl_tCg |title=Rebels retake al-Majbal area near the Aleppo central prison |publisher=Syriahr.com |date=2014-05-09 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} On 20 May, the Army captured the Sheikh Najjar power plant and Agop hill right next to it, which opened the way towards the central prison, bringing government troops to one kilometer from the prison complex.{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/index.php?option=com_news&nid=19270&Itemid=2&task=displaynews |title=1 kilometer separates the regime forces from the central prison of Aleppo |publisher=Syriahr.com |date=2014-05-20 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} There were also reports that some troops had already arrived to reinforce the prison.{{cite web|author=الإنتخابات |url=http://tahrirsouri.com/2014/05/21/%D8%AA%D8%B7%D9%88%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D9%85%D8%AA%D8%B3%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%B9%D8%A9-%D9%81%D9%8A-%D8%AD%D9%84%D8%A8-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%86%D8%B8%D8%A7%D9%85-%D9%8A%D9%86%D8%AC%D8%AD-%D8%A8%D9%81%D9%83/ |title=Rapid developments in Aleppo .. system works to break the siege on the Central Prison in Aleppo and news of his downfall |publisher=Tahrirsouri.com |date=2014-05-21 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} After the capture of the hill, the military attacked the village of Hilan,{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/index.php?option=com_news&nid=19269&Itemid=2&task=displaynews |title=System locked in fierce clashes in an attempt to decode Alhsaran central prison |publisher=Syriahr.com |date=2014-05-20 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} which is the last rebel stronghold before the prison. The Army was also still engaged in Sector 2 of the industrial complex.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/EjmAlrai/status/469011315558989824 |title=Elijah J Magnier |publisher=Twitter.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-29}} The next day, the military captured Hilan, as government forces had broken through on the road leading to the prison. At the same time, rebels blew up the Kindi hospital in fear it could be used for monitoring rebel supply routes if the advancing government troops managed to capture it.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/May-21/257295-syria-army-presses-bid-to-break-prison-siege-reports.ashx#axzz32Mc8BDkD |title=Syria army presses bid to break prison siege: reports |publisher=Dailystar.com.lb |date=2014-05-21 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} Soon after, Army tanks had reached and taken up positions at about 500 meters from the prison complex. The area was witnessing heavy artillery shelling, with government troops dropping at least 30 [[barrel bomb]]s from [[military helicopter]]s over the previous 24 hours, as rebel forces were fast retreating from the area due to the government's superior firepower.{{cite web|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/world/syrian-troops-inch-closer-to-seizing-aleppo-central-prison-1.1831393 |title=Syrian troops inch closer to seizing Aleppo central prison |publisher=Ctvnews.ca |date=2014-05-21 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} During the two days of fighting, at least 50 rebels were killed.{{cite web|url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/news/2014/05/21/50-rebels-killed-in-fighting-in-syria/ |title=50 Rebels killed in fighting in Syria |publisher=Latino.foxnews.com |date=2014-05-21 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} On 22 May, the Army had finally broken the siege of the prison as [[tank]]s and armored vehicles entered the complex.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/syria-army-breaks-rebel-siege-of-aleppo-central-prison-ngo.aspx?pageID=238&nID=66804&NewsCatID=352 |title=Syria army breaks rebel siege of Aleppo central prison: NGO |publisher=Hurriyetdailynews.com |date=2011-09-13 |accessdate=2014-05-29}}{{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2014/05/22/Syrian-troops-reach-besieged-Aleppo-prison.html |title=Syrian troops reach besieged Aleppo prison |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2014-05-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/May-22/257379-syrian-troops-reach-besieged-prison-in-aleppo.ashx |title=Assad's forces enter Syria's Aleppo prison: activists |publisher=Dailystar.com.lb |date=2014-05-22 |accessdate=2014-05-29}} The Air Force dropped more than 100 barrel bombs during the final push to reach the prison.{{cite web|last=Associated |first=The |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=314756078 |title=Syrian Troops Reach Besieged Prison In Aleppo |publisher=Npr.org |date=2014-05-22 |accessdate=2014-05-30}} This put the north-east approach to Aleppo under the control of government forces.{{cite web|author=Thomson Reuters Foundation |url=http://www.trust.org/item/20140522080640-unicr/?source=dpagehead |title=Assad's forces enter Syria's Aleppo prison - monitor |publisher=Trust.org |date= |accessdate=2014-05-30}} By 25 May, the military was in control of Sector 1 of the industrial zone and had captured the town of Jbeileh next to the prison.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/CdricLabrousse/status/470272075966316544 |title=The Arab Chronicle |publisher=Twitter.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-30}} On 30 May, the SOHR reported almost 2,000 people had been killed in Aleppo by barrel bomb strikes since the start of January.{{cite web|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/ngo-almost-2000-syrians-killed-by-barrel-bombs-in-2014/|title=NGO: Almost 2,000 Syrians killed by barrel bombs in 2014|work=The Times of Israel|accessdate=25 October 2014}} === Sheikh Najjar captured === On 3 July, after an assault which included 20 airstrikes, government forces fully captured the industrial district.{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/xinhua-news-agency/140703/syrian-army-recaptures-aleppos-industrial-city|title=Syrian army recaptures Aleppo's industrial city|work=GlobalPost|accessdate=25 October 2014}} This left the Infantry Academy and the Handarat camp as the only two rebel-held areas the Army would need to capture to complete the siege of Aleppo,{{cite web|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2014/07/aleppo-rebels-islamic-state-syria-regime-annihilation.html#|title=Aleppo rebels caught between Islamic State and regime|work=Al-Monitor|accessdate=25 October 2014}} after three major rebel supply routes had been cut.{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/parallels/2014/07/16/331995284/syrias-army-on-the-verge-of-retaking-the-countrys-largest-city|title=Syria's Army On The Verge Of Retaking The Country's Largest City|date=16 July 2014|work=NPR.org|accessdate=25 October 2014}} Days later, government reinforcements arrived, which included members of the elite Republican Guards and Hezbollah, and the military captured the villages of [[Kafr Saghir|Kafr al-Saghir]] and Moqbila, advancing towards the Infantry Academy.{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2014/07/07/syrian-troops-advance-in-largest-city|title=Syrian troops advance in and around the country's largest city of Aleppo|work=US News & World Report|accessdate=25 October 2014}} Rebel reinforcements had also been dispatched to Aleppo, however, one brigade numbering 1,000 fighters that was supposedly sent from Idlib province to reinforce opposition forces in Aleppo city used the chance and defected to the rival extremist [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ISIS]] organisation.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/2014/07/08/3992446/1000-syrian-rebels-defect-to-islamic.html|title=1,000 Syrian rebels defect to Islamic State in sign it’s still strengthening|publisher=|accessdate=25 October 2014}} The slow pace with which the Army advanced since the start of the operation was described as deliberate so the military could have time to consolidate control over captured territory. According to one diplomat, "They haven't lost any areas they have taken back. It is not a battle of back-and-forth."{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/r-syrian-government-forces-squeeze-insurgents-in-aleppo-2014-09|title=Syrian government forces squeeze insurgents in Aleppo|date=9 July 2014|work=Business Insider|accessdate=25 October 2014}} === Rebel counter-attacks repelled, continued Army advance === By mid-August, only three miles remained before the military could completely cut rebel supply lines into the city, after the opposition forces’ position deteriorated in the previous month following failed rebel counterattacks that attempted to dislodge government troops from the industrial zone. The rebels also attempted to capture the military academy in the western outskirts of the city, in an attempt to force government forces to reposition from the east to the west. However, the attack ended in catastrophe after the rebels were exposed to repeated air strikes, even at night, that made it impossible to move men and weapons freely.{{cite web|url=http://www.ledger-enquirer.com/2014/08/11/3243308/moderate-rebels-face-worsening.html|title=Moderate rebels face worsening situation in Aleppo|publisher=|accessdate=25 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812204546/http://www.ledger-enquirer.com/2014/08/11/3243308/moderate-rebels-face-worsening.html|archivedate=12 August 2014|df=}} Government forces had also captured two hills{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Aug-06/266198-isis-takes-brutal-revenge-on-tribal-insurgents-in-syria.ashx#axzz3ABaoNHre|title=ISIS takes brutal revenge on tribal insurgents in Syria|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=25 October 2014}} and three villages in the western Aleppo countryside,{{cite web|url=https://www.zamanalwsl.net/en/news/6125.html|title=Assad forces make advances in west Aleppo|work=SYRIA NEWS - ZAMAN ALWSL #syria|accessdate=25 October 2014}} while there were competing claims over the town of [[Khan Tuman]].{{cite web|url=http://syriadirect.org/rss/1481-syria-direct-news-update-8-6-2014|title=Syria Direct: News Update 8-6-2014|publisher=|accessdate=17 February 2015}} On 18 August, the Army captured Khan Tuman hill.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/syriahroe/posts/570910439683965|title=Aleppo Province|publisher=|accessdate=25 October 2014}} Between 20 and 23 August, heavy fighting raged at the Handarat district, which was reportedly being besieged by government forces, while the military claimed to had captured the village of Jbeileh, which the rebels used to conduct attacks on the prison.{{cite web|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-makes-substantial-gains-aleppo-governate/|title=The Syrian Army Makes Substantial Gains in the Aleppo Governate|author=Leith Fadel|work=Al-Masdar News|accessdate=25 October 2014}} Shortly after the capture of Jbeileh, the Army attacked the "cement factory", with expectations it would be captured within a few hours.{{cite web|url=http://farsnews.com/newstext.php?nn=13930601001082|title=Intense battles around Aleppo Cement Factory / Factory to release in few hours|publisher=|accessdate=25 October 2014}} {{anchor|mountazzan}}On 24 August, the military captured Mount Azzan, after forcing rebel forces to retreat to the south, while government troops advanced from Jbeileh to the west towards Al-Muslimiyyah and captured two neighborhoods in the village.{{cite web|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-liberates-mount-azzan-southern-aleppo/|title=Syrian Army Liberates Mount Azzan in Southern Aleppo|author=Leith Fadel|work=Al-Masdar News|accessdate=25 October 2014}} ===Battle for the Handarat area=== On 3 October, following a two-month stalemate,{{cite web|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/updated-battle-map-aleppo-handaraat-liberated-syrian-arab-army/|title=Updated Battle Map of Aleppo: Handaraat Liberated by the Syrian Arab Army|author=Leith Fadel|work=Al-Masdar News|accessdate=25 October 2014}} the Army, supported by the NDF, Hezbollah, Al-Quds Brigades and Ba'ath Brigades, finally captured the village of Handarat and its hill,{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/syriahroe/posts/591394617635547|title=Aleppo Province|publisher=|accessdate=25 October 2014}} thus cutting off one of the two last rebel supply lines for opposition-held areas in Aleppo city.{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/middleeast/la-fg-syria-aleppo-siege-20141123-story.html|title=Aleppo, Syria, could soon be under siege by government troops|author=Los Angeles Times|date=23 November 2014|work=latimes.com|accessdate=15 December 2014}} The Army quickly erected barriers on the road so it would be closed off.{{cite web|url=http://english.al-akhbar.com/node/21843|title=Syrian army clashes with rebels in Aleppo, regains full control of Handarat|work=Al Akhbar English|accessdate=25 October 2014}} Government forces also captured the villages of al-Mudafah and Sifat and a four-way intersection west of Sifat.{{cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/10/03/uk-syria-crisis-aleppo-idUKKCN0HS0ZU20141003|title=Syrian army seizes villages north of Aleppo - state TV|publisher=|accessdate=25 October 2014}} Later, the rebels counter-attacked in an attempt to recapture the hill.{{cite web|url=http://www.yourmiddleeast.com/news/syria-troops-threaten-rebel-supply-route-to-aleppo_27025|title=Syria troops threaten rebel supply route to Aleppo|work=Your Middle East|accessdate=25 October 2014}} 45 rebels{{cite web|url=http://www.syriahr.com/index.php?option=com_news&nid=24430&Itemid=2&task=displaynews#.VC9P2_mSyyE|title=Bhandarat violent clashes and the killing and the death of at least 65 from both sides|publisher=|accessdate=25 October 2014}} and 32 soldiers were killed during the day's fighting.{{cite web|url=http://www.syriahr.com/index.php?option=com_news&nid=24445&Itemid=2&task=displaynews#.VC_92vmSyyE|title=Continuing clashes and the killing of 32-element regime forces in Handarat|publisher=|accessdate=25 October 2014}} The final supply route, via the Castello Road and al-Jandul roundabout, came under constant air-strikes and was monitored. On 9 October, the Army secured the Handarat farms and the village of Babinnis, just south of the rebel-controlled infantry school.{{cite web|title=Syrian Army Captures West Handarat Farms and Babinnis; Ahrar Al-Sham Offensive in Safira is Repelled|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-captures-west-handarat-farms-babinnis-ahrar-al-sham-offensive-safira-repelled/|website=almasdarnews|accessdate=9 October 2014}} On 13 October, the rebels made advances that could possibly cut off the supply roads to the Army-held Sifat, Handarat and Handarat base.{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2014/10/al-nusra-and-the-battalions-have-advanced-in-handarat-and-sifat-areas/|title=Al Nusra and the battalions have advanced in Handarat and Sifat areas|author=SOHRadmin1|publisher=|accessdate=25 October 2014}} On 18 October, the Army captured the village of al-Jbayleh, the cement plant and the glass factory, north of the prison, ending the rebel's attempts to isolate the Army in Sifat and Handarat.{{cite web|title=The regime army could seize a village and a cement plant in Aleppo|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2014/10/the-regime-army-could-seize-a-village-and-a-cement-plant-in-aleppo/|website=SOHR|accessdate=18 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2014/10/20/Syrian-army-move-to-tighten-siege-on-Aleppo-.html|title=Siege looms over Aleppo as Assad’s regime gains ground|publisher=|accessdate=25 October 2014}} The next day, the Army also captured the village of Al-Muslimiyya.{{cite web|url=http://umap.openstreetmap.fr/fr/map/desyracuse-syria-iraq-20-october-2014_19652#13/36.3176/37.1928|title=Desyracuse|publisher=|accessdate=25 October 2014}}{{cite web|title=Updated Battle Map: SAA Captures Al-Muslimiyya|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/updated-battle-map-saa-captures-al-muslimiyya/|website=almasdarnews|accessdate=19 October 2014}} On 20 October, the military made further advances and captured the Halabi Farms (Mazra’a Halabi) and Tal Madafa, the highest hill in the province which is located north of Handarat.{{cite web|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-continues-advance-west-aleppo-tal-madafa-captured/|title=Syrian Army Continues Its Advance in West Aleppo; Tal Madafa Captured|author=Leith Fadel|work=Al-Masdar News|accessdate=25 October 2014}} In early November, the last remaining rebel supply route, the Castello Road, was within firing range of the Syrian Army and they were in position to close it off at any time, but were still leaving it open, possibly to give a chance to anyone who wanted to leave the city before they implemented the siege.{{cite web|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2014/11/6/u-s-anti-isil-strategyfacesmajorsetbackinsyriassecondcity.html|title=US anti-ISIL strategy faces major setback in Syria’s second city|publisher=|accessdate=15 December 2014}} == See also == {{portal|Syrian civil war}} * [[Battle of Aleppo (2012–2016)]] * [[Operation Rainbow (Syrian Civil War)]] == References == country after Mohacs but the Habsburg rulers remained the legitimate sovereign Kings of Hungary after the Diet of Bratislava| place=[[Central Europe]] ([[Kingdom of Hungary]]), [[Eastern Europe]] ([[Moldavia]]), [[Balkans]] ([[Bulgaria]], [[Kosovo]], [[Serbia]], and [[Wallachia]]) | result=[[Battle of Mohács|Ottoman victory]], Hungarian Kingdom partitioned, [[Ottoman–Habsburg wars|war continues between the Habsburgs and Ottomans]]| strength1= c. 20,000{{cite book|last=Grant|first=R.G.|title=Battle a Visual Journey Through 5000 Years of Combat|location=London|publisher=Dorling Kindersley|year=2005|pages=122}} The Hungarians, with Vlad the Impaler had some 30,000 men whilst at Mohacs there was roughly 20,000 men–60,000In 1521, The Hungarian Royal army had an initial strength of 60,000| strength2= Capable of raising 100,000 men| combatant1={{plainlist| *[[File:Coa Hungary Country History (19th Century).svg|35x24px]] [[Kingdom of Hungary in the Middle Ages|Kingdom of Hungary]] **[[File:Coat of arms of Croatia 1495.svg|30x20px]] [[Croatia in personal union with Hungary|Kingdom of Croatia]] *[[Image:Chorągiew królewska króla Zygmunta III Wazy.svg|22px]] Hungary Country History (19th Century).svg|35x24px]] [[Kings of Hungary]] *{{flagicon|Wallachia}} [[Voivode|Voivodes of Wallachia]] *{{flagicon|Moldavia}} [[Voivode|Voivodes of Moldavia]] *[[File:Coat of arms of the Serbian Despotate.svg|30x20px]] [[Despot (court title)|Despotes of Serbia]]}} |commander2=[[File:Flag of the Ottoman Empire (1453-1517).svg|27x17px]] [[Ottoman Sultans]]| combatant2=[[File:Flag of the Ottoman Empire (1453-1517).svg|27x17px]] [[Ottoman Empire]]}} {{Campaignbox Ottoman-Hungarian War}} The '''Ottoman–Hungarian Wars''' were a series of battles between the [[Ottoman Empire]] and the medieval [[Kingdom of Hungary in the Middle Ages|Kingdom of Hungary]]. Following the [[Byzantium under the Palaiologoi|Byzantine Civil War]], the Ottoman [[Fall of Gallipoli|capture of Gallipoli]], and the decisive [[Battle of Kosovo]], the Ottoman Empire was poised to conquer the entirety of the Balkans and also sought and expressed desire to expand further north into [[Central Europe]] beginning with the Hungarian lands. Initial Hungarian success culminated in the [[Crusade of Varna]], though without significant outside support the Hungarians were defeated. Nonetheless the Ottomans suffered more [[Siege of Belgrade (1456)|defeats at Belgrade]], even after the [[Fall of Constantinople|conquest of Constantinople]]. In particular, the notorious [[Vlad III Dracula|Vlad the Impaler]], with limited Hungarian help, resisted Ottoman rule until the Ottomans placed his brother, a man less feared and less hated by the populace, on the throne of [[Wallachia]]. Ottoman success was once again halted at Moldavia due to Hungarian intervention, but the Turks finally succeeded when Moldavia and then Belgrade fell to [[Bayezid II]] and [[Suleiman the Magnificent]], respectively. In 1526 the Ottomans crushed the Hungarian army at [[Battle of Mohács|Mohács]] with King [[Louis II of Hungary]] perishing along with 14,000-20,000 of his foot soldiers.Turner & Corvisier & Childs, ''A Dictionary of Military History and the Art of War'', pp. 365–366 "In 1526, at the battle of Mohács, the Hungarian army was destroyed by the Turks. King Louis II died, along with 7 bishops, 28 barons and most of his army (4,000 cavalry and 10,000 infantry)."
Minahan, ''One Europe, many nations: a historical dictionary of European national groups'', p. 311 "A peasant uprising, crushed in 1514, was followed by defeat by the Ottoman Turks at the decisive battle of Mohacs in 1526. King Louis II and more than 20,000 of his men perished in battle, which marked the end of Hungarian power in Central Europe." Following this defeat, the eastern region of the Kingdom of Hungary (mainly [[Transylvania]]) became an Ottoman [[tributary state]], constantly engaged in [[civil war]] with [[Royal Hungary]]. The war continued with the [[Habsburgs]] now asserting primacy in the conflict with [[Ottoman Sultans|Suleiman and his successors]]. The northern and most of the central parts of Hungary managed to remain free from Ottoman rule, but the Kingdom of Hungary, the most powerful state east of Vienna under [[Matthias, Holy Roman Emperor|Matthias II]], was now divided and constantly threatened by Ottoman ambitions in the region. ==Background== In the century after the death of [[Osman I]] in 1326, Ottoman rule began to extend over the eastern Mediterranean and the Balkans. The important city of [[Thessaloniki]] was captured from the Venetians in 1387,{{citation needed|date=January 2013}} and the Turkish victory at the [[Battle of Kosovo]] in 1389 effectively marked the end of Serbian power in the region, paving the way for Ottoman expansion into the rest of Europe.{{citation needed|date=January 2013}} ==Balkan and Turkish wars of Louis the Great== In 1344 [[Louis I of Hungary]], who would rule from 1342–1382 and earn the epithet "the Great", invaded [[Wallachia]] and [[Moldavia]] and established a system of vassalage.Ion Grumeza: The Roots of Balkanization: Eastern Europe C.E. 500-1500, University Press of America, 2010 [https://books.google.com/books?id=QKhuxLdnYhMC&pg=PA91] Louis and his 80,000 strong army repelled the Serbian [[Stefan Uroš IV Dušan of Serbia|Dušan's]] armies in the duchies of [[Mačva]] and principality of [[Travunia]] in 1349. When Czar Dušan broke into [[Bosnia]]n territory he was defeated by Bosnian [[Stjepan II Kotromanić|Stjepan II]] with the assistance of Louis' troops, and when Dušan made a second attempt he was decisively beaten by Louis in 1354.https://archive.org/stream/austriahungarywa00ludwrich/austriahungarywa00ludwrich_djvu.txt The two monarchs signed a peace agreement in 1355. [[File:1396-Battle of Nicopolis-Hunername-2.jpg|thumb|170px|The [[Battle of Nicopolis]], as depicted by Turkish miniaturist]] His latter campaigns in the Balkans were aimed not so much at conquest and subjugation as at drawing the Serbs, Bosnians, Wallachians and Bulgarians into the fold of the Roman Catholic faith and at forming a united front against the Turks. It was relatively easy to subdue the Balkan Orthodox countries by arms, but to convert them was a different matter. Despite Louis' efforts, the peoples of the Balkans remained faithful to the Eastern Orthodox Church and their attitude toward Hungary remained ambiguous. Louis annexed [[Moldavia]] in 1352 and established a vassal principality there, before conquering Vidin in 1365. The rulers of Serbia, Walachia, Moldavia, and Bulgaria became his vassals. They regarded powerful Hungary as a potential menace to their national identity. For this reason, Hungary could never regard the Serbs and Wallachians as reliable allies in subsequent wars against the Turks. In the spring of 1365, Louis headed a campaign against the [[Bulgaria]]n [[Tsardom of Vidin]] and its ruler [[Ivan Sratsimir of Bulgaria|Ivan Sratsimir]]. He seized the city of [[Vidin]] on 2 May 1365; the [[Hungarian occupation of Vidin|region was under Hungarian rule]] until 1369.{{cite book | last = Божилов | first = Иван | year = 1994 | title = Фамилията на Асеневци (1186–1460). Генеалогия и просопография | location = София | publisher = [[Bulgarian Academy of Sciences|Българска академия на науките]] | language = Bulgarian |oclc=38087158 |isbn=954-430-264-6 |chapter=Иван Срацимир, цар във Видин (1352–1353 — 1396) |pages=202–203 }} In 1366 Byzantine Emperor [[John V Palaiologos|John V]] visited Hungary to beg for help against the Ottoman Turks, who were in increasing conflict with the Balkan vassal states. Louis defeated the Turks when Hungarian and Turkish troops clashed for the first time in history at Nicapoli in 1366. He defeated the Turkish army in [[Wallachia]] in 1374. The [[Battle of Nicopolis]] (25 September 1396) is thought to be the first large-scale encounter between Hungary and the Ottoman Empire, where a broad alliance of Christian monarchs and the [[Knights Hospitaller]] were defeated by a numerically superior Turkish army (the Ottomans had also enlisted the support of their new vassal, the [[Serbian Despotate]]).{{citation needed|date=January 2013}} ==Timur and the Ottoman Interregnum== {{see also| Ottoman Interregnum}} Despite these successes the Ottomans were dealt a major setback when at [[Battle of Ankara|Ankara]] in 1402 Timur of the [[Chagatai Khanate]] captured the Ottoman Sultan [[Bayezid the Thunderbolt]] (so named for the speed of his crushing victories against his Christian opponents, most notably at [[Crusade of Nicopolis|Nicopolis]]). After a decade of internecine battles, [[Mehmed I]] emerged victorious and reestablished the Ottoman Empire, although under the suzerainty of the Byzantine Emperor. ==Campaigns of Murad II, 1421–1451== [[Murad II]], the successor to Mehmed I, proved to be a man of far greater military skills then his peaceful predecessor. In 1422, no longer professing suzerainty to the Byzantines, he [[Siege of Constantinople (1422)|laid siege]] to Constantinople, which narrowly avoided becoming an Ottoman conquest. However he had managed to capture lands surrounding Constantinople. {{citation needed|date=January 2013}} With Byzantium no longer a threat, Murad II began his war against his Christian opponents, attacking Macedonia and capturing Thessalonika from the Venetians in 1430. Between 1435 and 1436 the Ottomans made a show of strength in Albania, but the country survived due to intervention from the Kingdom of Hungary, whose borders now neared those of the Ottoman Empire.{{citation needed|date=January 2013}} ==Campaigns of John Hunyadi== {{unreferenced section|date=April 2012}} In the 1440s and 1450s, the Hungarian military leader [[John Hunyadi]] became the key architect of campaigns against the Ottoman Empire. In 1441 he scored a pitched battle victory at [[Smederevo|Semendria]] over [[Ishak Bey]]. The following year, he annihilated an Ottoman force invading Transylvania at [[Sibiu]].{{citation needed|date = January 2013}} Following this victory, Wallachia again accepted the suzerainty of the Kingdom of Hungary.{{citation needed|date = January 2013}} With the help of knights from western Europe, Hunyadi succeeded in capturing [[Niš|Nis]] on November 3, 1443, defeating another Turkish army as they crossed the Balkan Mountains and then taking another victory on Christmas Day. Because supplies for the Crusader army were low, Hunyadi concluded a ten-year peace treaty with Murad II, presumably on Hunyadi's terms, for it was the triumphant Hungarian that entered [[Buda]] in February 1444. Ten years was the maximum time permitted by Islamic law for a treaty with an "infidel". The peace was short lived, as Cardinal [[Julian Cesarini]] incited the Hungarians to break the treaty and attack the Turks once more. However, much of the Crusader armies' strength had been reduced due to the loss (by defection) of Serbia, Albania and the Byzantine Empire. ===Battle of Varna=== {{main|Battle of Varna}} The Crusader army attacked across the Danube. Murad, upon hearing of the Christian breach of the treaty, is said to have mounted the broken treaty on his standard and said the words, "Christ, if you are God as your followers claim, punish them for their perfidy".{{citation needed|date=February 2013}} The two armies met on November 10, 1444 near [[Varna]] in eastern [[Bulgaria]]. Accounts vary as to how many troops were present but the Crusaders may have been 30,000 strong whilst the Ottoman forces were two to three times larger. Nonetheless, Hunyadi's successful defense wagons held the line until [[Władysław III of Poland|King Ladislas]] led a charge to his death against the Turkish lines. His head was mounted on a spear where all the defeated Crusaders could see it. Few Crusaders survived the battle, although Hunyadi did escape with his life. [[File:Battle of Varna 1444.PNG|thumb|right|[[Battle of Varna]]]] ===After Varna=== The Hungarians recovered their strength after Varna and Hunyadi was able to lead another expedition down the Danube. Turkish counter-attacks saw this "crusade" driven back. After Murad dealt with the Greeks at the Peloponesse and others who had fought him at Varna, he turned his attention to Albania, whose leader, once an Ottoman hostage, was now a popular resistance leader. Hunyadi could not refuse an offer to fight the Turks and in 1448 an army of some 24,000 Hungarians marched south into Serbia. At the [[Battle of Kosovo (1448)|Second Battle of Kosovo]] Murad scored another victory against the Hungarians. This time, Hunyadi had had enough and was unable to campaign against the Ottoman Sultan. Murad II passed on his powers to his successor, [[Mehmed II]]. Thanks to such victories, the Ottoman forces were able to [[Fall of Constantinople|capture Constantinople]] in 1453 with only the Italians offering minimal support to the Byzantines. ===Battle of Belgrade (1456)=== Meanwhile, the Ottoman issue had again become acute, and, after the [[fall of Constantinople]] in 1453, [[Ottoman Dynasty|Sultan]] [[Mehmed II]] was rallying his resources to subjugate Hungary. His immediate objective was Nándorfehérvár (today Belgrade). Nándorfehérvár was a major castle-fortress, and a gatekeeper of south Hungary. The fall of this stronghold would have opened a clear way to the heart of Central Europe. Hunyadi arrived at the [[Siege of Belgrade (1456)|Siege of Belgrade]] at the end of 1455, after settling differences with his domestic enemies. At his own expense, he restocked the supplies and arms of the fortress, leaving a strong garrison there under the command of his brother-in-law [[Mihály Szilágyi]] and his own eldest son [[László Hunyadi]]. He proceeded to form a relief army, and assembled a fleet of two hundred ships. His main ally was the [[Franciscan]] [[friar]], [[Giovanni da Capistrano]], whose fiery oratory drew a large [[crusade]] made up mostly of peasants. Although relatively ill-armed (most were armed with farm equipment, such as [[scythe]]s and [[pitchfork]]s) they flocked to Hunyadi and his small corps of seasoned [[mercenary|mercenaries]] and [[cavalry]]. [[File:Battle of Nandorfehervar.jpg|thumb|right|Battle of Nándorfehérvár, Hungarian painting from the 19th century. In the middle [[Giovanni da Capistrano|Kapisztrán János]] with the cross in his hand.]] On July 14, 1456 the [[flotilla]] assembled by Hunyadi destroyed the Ottoman fleet. On July 21, Szilágyi's forces in the fortress repulsed a fierce assault by the [[Rumelia]]n army, and Hunyadi pursued the retreating forces into their camp, taking advantage of the Turkish army's confused flight from the city. After fierce but brief fighting, the camp was captured, and Mehmet raised the siege and returned to [[Istanbul|Constantinople]]. With his flight began a 70-year period of relative peace on Hungary's southeastern border. However, plague broke out in Hunyadi's camp three weeks after the lifting of the siege, and he died on August 11. He was buried inside the ([[Roman Catholic]]) [[Cathedral]] of [[Alba Iulia]] (''Gyulafehérvár''), next to his younger brother John. Sultan Mehmet II paid him tribute: "Although he was my enemy I feel grief over his death, because the world has never seen such a man."{{citation needed|date=February 2013}} During the battle, Pope Callixtus III had ordered the bells of every European church to be rung every day at noon, as a call for believers to pray for the defenders of Belgrade. However, in many countries (like England and the Spanish kingdoms), news of the victory arrived before the order, and the ringing of the church bells at noon thus transformed into a commemoration of the victory. The pope never withdrew the order, and many Catholic and older Protestant churches still ring the noon bell to this day. ==Turkish wars of Matthias Corvinus (1458–1490)== [[File:The wars of Matthias Corvinus of Hungary (1458-1490).png|right|thumb|300px|Military actions of Matthias Corvinus and the [[Black Army of Hungary|Black Army]]{{cite map |publisher = Kartográfiai Vállalat |title = Történelmi világatlasz |trans-title= Historical Worldmaps |year = 1991 |scale = 1 : 10.000.000 |page = 112 |section = V |isbn = 963-351-696-X }} {{cite book |last=Fenyvesi |first=László |title=[http://www.odrportal.hu/web/guest/record/-/record/MOKKAI0009039680 Mátyás Király fekete serege] |trans-title=The Black Army of King Matthias |series=Hadtörténelem fiataloknak |year=1990 |publisher=Zrínyi Katonai Kiadó |location=[[Budapest]], [[Hungary]] |language=Hungarian |isbn=978-9633270172 }} ]] Hunyadi's son [[Matthias Corvinus]] was crowned king in [[Buda]] in 1458 at the age of 15. In 1471 Matthias renewed the [[Serbian Despotate]] in south Hungary under [[Vuk Grgurević]] for the protection of the borders against the Ottomans. In 1479 an Ottoman army, on its return home from ravaging Transylvania, was annihilated at Szászváros (modern [[Orăştie]], 13 October 1479) in the [[Battle of Breadfield]]. The following year Matthias recaptured Jajce, drove the Ottomans from northern Serbia and instituted two new military [[banat]]s, Jajce and Srebernik, from reconquered Bosnian territory. [[File:Kenyérmezői csata.jpg|thumb|left|Battle of Breadfield]] In 1480 an Ottoman fleet [[siege of Otranto|seized Otranto]] in the Kingdom of Naples. At the earnest solicitation of the pope Matthias sent the Hungarian general, Balázs Magyar, to recover the fortress, which surrendered on 10 May 1481. Again in 1488, Matthias took [[Ancona]] under his protection for a while, occupying it with a Hungarian garrison. ==Wallachian and Moldavian wars== ===Vlad the Impaler and war with Wallachia, 1456–1475=== Mehmed II's post-Constantinople troubles escalated further when the [[Balkan]] [[principality]] of [[Wallachia]] under Count [[Vlad III Dracul]] rebelled against the Ottoman Empire and declared the King of Hungary as his [[suzerain]]. The main drive for these actions was Vlad's return to his homeland after being in exile as a hostage of the Ottoman sultan. In 1461, five years after his return, Vlad initiated war with the Turks when he impaled the Turkish ambassadors demanding tribute from him and took the fortress of [[Giurgiu]]. Vlad then began a bloody assault across the Danube to the Black Sea, destroying as many of the ports as he could to prevent Ottoman naval attacks. Ottoman attempts to subdue Vlad militarily proved a failure, but his cruelty, which had terrorized his enemies, proved to be his undoing. When Mehmed offered the populace the choice of Vlad or his brother [[Radu cel Frumos|Radu]], the populace chose Radu and soon Vlad was again an exile on the run. An attempt to return a few years afterwards ended in his death in battle. ===Stephen the Great and war against Moldavia, 1475–1476=== Mehmed's army seems to have spent itself in Wallachia for the campaign against the [[Moldavia]]ns was shorter and yielded poorer results. In 1475 Mehmed ordered an invasion of Moldavia. Again, the Ottomans often took possession of the field but Moldavian hit-and-run tactics proved effective against the Turks. Poor roads further slowed the Ottomans until [[Stephen the Great]] was able to concentrate his forces at Vaslui. An Ottoman offensive was held in check and then finally driven from the field on 10 January 1475. The Ottomans returned in 1476, this time assisted by their allies from Crimea, the Tartars and their newly conquered Vassal of Wallachia. Stephen knew that he did not have the resources to defend his people and evacuated them to the mountains. After a failed attack on the Ottoman vanguard Stephen seemed on the brink of defeat when King Matthias Corvinus of Hungary offered assistance. The Ottomans withdrew when the Hungarians began moving in and fighting did not resume until 1484. ==Bayezid II, 1481–1512== The early reign of [[Bayezid II]] included a small civil war against his brother Jem, who escaped to the west. There European leaders entertained ideas of installing a pro-Western sultan while sending a crusade to the Balkans. Consequently, Bayezid did not incite any serious wars with his Christian opponents until his brother's death in 1495. In the meantime Bayezid signed a ten-year peace with Hungary in 1484, although this did not prevent a defeat of an Ottoman army at Villach in 1493. Between 1484 and 1486 Bayezid campaigned annually against Moldavia in an attempt to subdue it and link up with Crimea, his Muslim vassal and ally. Despite two defeats in 1485 and 1486 Moldavia was subjugated. As Bayezid's reign drew to a close he was entangled in a civil war between his sons Ahmed and Selim. Eventually Selim took the throne in 1512 and for the next eight years continued minor conquests in the west, although his main achievement was the conquest of the [[Mamluke Sultanate]]. It would be Selim's successor, Suleiman who would continue the war against Hungary. ==Campaigns of Suleiman the Magnificent, 1520–1566== {{unreferenced section|date=June 2017}} [[Suleiman the Magnificent]] resumed the war against Hungary by attacking the city of [[Belgrade]], the same settlement that had defied Mehmed II over half a century earlier. Despite strong resistance, the city fell to Suleiman. In 1522 Suleiman took his army to a strategically successful siege of Rhodes, allowing the Knights Hospital to evacuate for the fort. ===Battle of Mohács=== {{Main|Battle of Mohács}} [[File:2lajos.jpg|thumb|right|Discovery of the Corpse of King Louis II]] When Suleiman launched an invasion in 1526 the Grand Vizier constructed a great bridge ahead of the Sultan allowing his army to march into Hungary. Despite eighty days of marching and taking five days to cross the [[Danube River]], the Ottomans met no resistance from the Hungarians. The original plan of Hungarian King [[Louis II of Hungary|Louis II]] had been to send a vanguard to hold the Danube where the Ottomans were expected to cross, yet the nobles of the Kingdom refused to follow the King's deputy in battle, claiming that they did so out of zealous allegiance to the King (and would therefore only follow him). Consequently, when King Louis II took the field his army of 36,000 men seemed to be doomed to fail against the Ottomans' 80,000.Sources such as this {{cite book|last=Stephen|first=Turnbull|title=The Ottoman Empire 1326–1699 |location=New York |publisher=Osprey |year=2003 |page=46}} support this number, other suggest a smaller number of 60,000 At Mohács the plains of Hungary allowed the heavier Christian knights to launch an effective charge. As the Hungarian knights brushed aside first the [[Akinjis]] and then the [[Sipahis]], the Ottoman cavalry regrouped and flanked the Knights inflicting a moderate amount of casulties. The Sultan then placed his Janissaries and cannon into position chained up as an effective line . The Hungarian cavalry took serious casualties from the skilfully handled Turkish artillery. With the cavalry annihilated, the infantry suffered immense casualties as the weight of numbers of the Ottomans and their skill in battle took their toll. When Suleiman the Magnificent found the body of Louis II he is said to have been saddened by his untimely death. ===Aftermath of Mohács=== [[John Zápolya]], who had been instructed by Louis II to raid the enemy's supply lines, arrived at the battle too late and fled the scene. Suleiman, however, was not ready to annex the Kingdom completely into the Ottoman realm and in that power gap, Zapolya was chosen by Hungarian electorate as their ruler. Meanwhile, at the Diet of Bratislava Archduke Ferdinand of Austria was declared King of Hungary. The surviving nobles of Hungary now had to choose between pledging allegiance to a native vassal of Suleiman and a Christian "foreigner". [[File:Johann Peter Krafft 005.jpg|thumb|right|[[Nikola Šubić Zrinski]]'s Charge from the Fortress of [[Siege of Szigetvár|Szigetvár]]]] ===After Zapolya's death=== Zápolya would rule Hungary until his death in 1540. Following his demise, Hungary was split into three parts. The north-west (present-day Slovakia, western Transdanubia and Burgenland, western Croatia and parts of north-eastern present-day Hungary) remained under Habsburg rule; although initially independent, later it became a part of the Habsburg Monarchy under the informal name Royal Hungary. The Habsburg Emperors would from then on be also crowned as Kings of Hungary. [[File:Székely, Bertalan - The Women of Eger - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|right|The Women of [[Siege of Eger (1552)|Eger]]]] The eastern part of the kingdom (Partium and Transylvania) became at first an independent principality, but gradually was brought under Turkish rule as a vassal state of the Ottoman Empire. The remaining central area (most of present-day Hungary), including the capital of Buda, became a province of the Ottoman Empire. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Sources== * {{Cite book|ref=harv|last=Ćirković|first=Sima|authorlink=Sima Ćirković|year=2004|title=The Serbs|location=Malden|publisher=Blackwell Publishing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2Wc-DWRzoeIC}} {{Hungary articles}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ottoman-Hungarian Wars}} [[Category:Kingdom of Hungary]] [[Category:Ottoman period in Hungary]] [[Category:15th-century conflicts]] [[Category:16th-century conflicts]] [[Category:Wars involving the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:Wars involving Hungary]] [[Category:Early Modern history of Hungary]] [[Category:Territorial evolution of Hungary]] [[Category:15th century in Hungary]] [[Category:16th century in Hungary]]

{{Infobox event|title=Pepsi Fruit Juice Flood|date=April 25, 2017|time=|place=[[Lebedyan]], [[Russia]] and the [[Don River]]|cause=Pepsi warehouse collapse}}
The '''Pepsi Fruit Juice Flood''', also known as '''Pepsi’s Fruit Juice Release''', was a flood of 176,000 barrels (28 million liters) of fruit and vegetable juices into the streets of [[Lebedyan]], [[Russia]] and the [[Don River]], caused by the collapse of a [[PepsiCo]] warehouse.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/list/7-strange-disasters|title=The Great Molasses Flood and 6 Other Strange Disasters|last=Rafferty|first=John P.|date=|website=Encyclopædia Britannica|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 11, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://tv.mk.ru/video/2017/04/25/kiselnye-berega-v-lebedyani-proizoshlo-navodnenie-iz-tysyach-litrov-soka.html|title=Кисельные берега: в Лебедяни произошло наводнение из тысяч литров сока|last=|first=|date=April 25, 2017|work=Moskovsky Komsolets|access-date=November 11, 2018|language=ru}}</ref>
On April 25, 2017, a PepsiCo warehouse's roof collapsed unexpectedly. The warehouse was located in Lebedyan, the center of Pepsi's operations in Russia, and operated by [[Lebedyansky (company)|Lebedyansky]]. The warehouse contained storage containers housing a variety of fruit and vegetable juices. The collapse of the roof caused two injuries and sent 28 million liters of juices into the streets of Lebedyan and the Don River. However, no deaths resulted from the spill.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2017/04/25/a-pepsi-warehouse-in-russia-just-collapsed-and-flooded-a-town/|title=A Pepsi Warehouse in Russia Just Collapsed and Flooded a Town|last=Smith|first=Geoffrey|date=April 25, 2017|work=Fortune|access-date=November 11, 2018}}</ref>
Pineapple, apricot, tangerine, grape, mango, pomegranate, apple, cherry, orange, grapefruit and tomato juices were all part of the spill.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.telesurenglish.net/news/Russian-Town-Flooded-by-28-Million-Litres-of-PepsiCo-Juice-20170502-0004.html|title=Russian Town Flooded by 28 Million Liters of PepsiCo Juices|last=|first=|date=May 2, 2017|work=TeleSur|access-date=November 11, 2018}}</ref> There was some concern that the juices might have damaged the aquatic ecosystem of the Don River, but water samples showed that there was no evidence of environmental damage caused by the spill.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/town-flooded-28-million-litres-10302667|title=Town flooded by 28 million litres of Pepsi after soft drink factory collapse|last=McDougall|first=Zoey|date=April 26, 2017|work=Mirror|access-date=November 11, 2018}}</ref>
Pepsi officials apologized for the incident, offered to pay for all damages caused, and stated that they were working with local officials to determine the cause of the warehouse collapse.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" />
