{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox person |name = Vanessa Williams |image = File:VanessaWilliamsHWoFMar2012.jpg |image_size = |alt = |caption = Williams in 2004. |known_for = [[Miss America]] (First [[African American]]) – 1984 | title = [[Miss America 1984]]
[[Miss New York]] 1983
Miss Syracuse 1983 | term = September 17, 1983 – July 22, 1984 (resigned) | predecessor = [[Debra Maffett]] | successor = [[Suzette Charles]] | awards =Preliminary Talent (Voice), "[[Happy Days Are Here Again#Other versions|Happy Days Are Here Again]]"
Preliminary Swimsuit }} '''[[Vanessa Williams]]''' (born March 18, 1963) is an American actress, singer, and fashion designer. She initially gained recognition as the first [[African American]] winner of the [[Miss America]] title when she was crowned [[Miss America 1984]] in September 1983. Several weeks before the end of her reign, however, a scandal arose when ''[[Penthouse (magazine)|Penthouse]]'' magazine bought and published unauthorized nude photographs of Williams. Williams was pressured to relinquish her title, and was succeeded by the first runner-up, [[Miss New Jersey]] 1983, [[Suzette Charles]]. Thirty-two years later, in September 2015, when Williams served as head judge for the [[Miss America 2016]] pageant, former Miss America CEO Sam Haskell made a public apology to her for the events of 1984. ==Miss America 1984== {{quote box|width=35%|align=right|quote=[I had] no idea that winning a Miss America title in 1983 would actually be so significant to people that had lived through the [[civil rights movement]]. And that to me was such an honor but also something that I had no idea the weight, and that there might be some bad consequences. To have white people who wanted to kill me because I was black and to have death threats against my family because they felt that I was tarnishing the Miss America crown because I was a black person. So it was an incredible time.|source=—Vanessa Williams in 2011 ([[Who Do You Think You Are? (U.S. TV series)#Season 2 .282011.29|Who Do You Think You Are?]]){{cite web |url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/who-do-you-think-you-are/episode-1-season-2/vanessa-williams/296860/ |title=Who Do You Think You Are?: Season 2, Episode 1, Vanessa Williams (February, 2011) |accessdate=2015-12-05 |last= |first= |date=2011-02-04 |publisher=[[Who Do You Think You Are? (U.S. TV series)#Season 2 .282011.29|Who Do You Think You Are?]] }}}} When she was 20 years old, Williams was approached by scouts from the Miss Syracuse pageant who had seen her perform while a student at [[Syracuse University]]. Despite their encouragement, Williams was not interested in participating in the pageant. She later changed her mind when she realized that she could earn scholarship money.{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2012/05/10/152422159/vanessa-williams-on-scandals-tv-and-her-mom |title=Vanessa Williams On Scandals, TV And Her Mom |accessdate=2015-09-14 |last=Martin |first=Michael |date=2010-05-10 |publisher=NPR (National Public Radio) }} Although she had never participated in a beauty pageant before, she won the title of Miss Syracuse in April 1983. She then went on to win [[Miss New York]] in July 1983 During the preliminaries for the [[Miss America]] pageant, Williams won "Preliminary Swimsuit" and "Preliminary Talent" (with a vocal performance of "[[Happy Days Are Here Again#Other versions|Happy Days Are Here Again]]"). She was also crowned [[Miss America 1984]] on September 17, 1983, becoming the first [[African American]] woman to win the title.{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/african-american-usa-crowned-1983-article-1.2353418 |title=Vanessa Williams is crowned the first African-American Miss America in 1983 |accessdate=2015-09-14 |last=Singleton |first=Don |date=1983-09-18 |publisher=''[[New York Daily News]]'' }}{{Cite news|title=Vanessa Williams's ancestry revealed: One great great grandfather escaped slavery... the other was a politician who left 'a legacy more precious than gold{{'-}}|date=February 6, 2011|work=[[Daily Mail]]|location=London|quote={{-'}}As an African American growing up here in the States, there are a lot of records that we don't have.{{'-}}}}{{Cite news|title=A New York Debut|url=http://www.people.com/people/vanessa_williams/biography/0,,,00.html|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}{{Cite news|title=A Look Black: Vanessa Williams Crowned Miss America In 1983|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/09/17/vanessa-williams-miss-america-anniversary_n_1891516.html|date=September 17, 2012|first=Julee|last=Wilson|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}{{Cite news|title=Vanessa Williams|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/2300-207_162-3193913.html|publisher=[[CBS News]]|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}{{cite news |url=http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/vanessa-williams-becomes-first-black-miss-america |title=This Day in History – Sep 17, 1983: Vanessa Williams becomes first black Miss America |publisher= [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History.com]] |accessdate=November 28, 2010}} During her reign as Miss America, Williams was criticized in some venues for winning. She later stated that "there were a lot of people that did not want me to be representative of the United States and Miss America. And not just white people alone. There were a lot of people who had issues [...] I was too light. My eyes were the wrong color. My hair wasn't the right texture and getting criticism for being who I was."{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/video/vanessa-williams-faith-10585404 |title=Vanessa Williams on Her Faith |accessdate=2016-05-06 |last= |first= |date=2010 |publisher=ABC News }} She was also the target of persistent racist hate mail and death threats (which she documented in her memoir, ''You Have No Idea'').{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/missamerica/peopleevents/e_inclusion.html |title=People & Events: Breaking the Color Line at the Pageant |publisher=PBS}} Thirty years later, when [[Miss America 2014]] [[Nina Davuluri]] (who was also a former Miss New York and Miss Syracuse) became the target of a racist social media backlash, Williams recounted the similarities with her own experiences, stating that she "wrote a book about everything that I went through, and I spent a lot of time talking about the death threats, the FBI, the sharpshooters ... it was a graver situation and more dangerous years ago—the change that was happening and the uproar because of the color of my skin."{{cite web |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/09/21/vanessa-williams-the-first-black-miss-america-on-nina-davuluri-and-racism.html |title=Vanessa Williams, the First Black Miss America, On Nina Davuluri and Racism |accessdate= |last=Stern |first=Marlow |date=September 21, 2013 |publisher= [[The Daily Beast]] }} Williams would later comment that she was one of five minority contestants that year, noting that ballet dancer [[Deneen Graham]] "had already had a cross burned on her front yard because she was the first black [[Miss North Carolina]] [1983]." She also pointed out that "[[Suzette Charles]] was the first runner-up, and she was biracial. But when the press started, when I would go out on the - on the tour and do my appearances, and people would come up and say they never thought they'd see the day that it would happen; when people would want to shake my hand, and you'd see tears in their eyes, and they'd say, I never thought I'd see it in my lifetime - that's when, you know, it was definitely a very special honor." ===Resignation=== {{quote box|width=35%|align=right|quote=It began in the summer of 1982. I had finished my exams the first week of May at [[Syracuse University]] and came home to find a summer job. I saw an advertisement in a local newspaper reading "models wanted," so I called up and talked to Tom Chiapel, who was the photographer and part-owner of TEC studios. He said to come down for an interview ... When I returned later to pick up the proofs, Tom Chiapel indicated that he needed a makeup artist. He offered me an audition, so I came in and did a face. He decided to have me work for him as a makeup artist-receptionist ... I had worked there for a month and a half when Tom Chiapel mentioned several times that he'd like to shoot me in the nude. I had never posed nude and I was curious. I was 19 years old. I agreed. He assured me that none of the photographs would ever leave the studio. He assured me ... I trusted him not to do anything with the photographs. That was my error. I did not give my consent to him or ''Penthouse'' to ever have them published, used in any magazine or in any way. Nothing. I signed an application giving my height, weight, color of hair and my talents ... I never told anyone about the pictures, not even my parents. I did not think it was a concern. We had made an agreement they would never be published. I feel as if I were just a sacrificial lamb. The past just came up and kicked me. I felt betrayed and violated, like I had been raped.|source=—Vanessa Williams in 1984"[http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20088398,00.html Vanessa's Story: The morning after Miss America 1984 talked with Assistant Editor Brenda Eady about the events leading to her abdication-and her hopes for the future]." ''[[People (magazine)|People Magazine]]'' Vol. 22, No.6, August 6, 1984: pp.85-87.}} In July 1984 (two months before the end of her reign), Williams learned that nude photos of her, taken before her involvement with the pageant, would be published without her consent in a future issue of ''[[Penthouse (magazine)|Penthouse]]''. Williams believed that the private photographs had been destroyed; she stated that she never signed a release permitting publication or use of the photos in a public format.{{cite web |url=http://www.biography.com/people/vanessa-williams-9542151 |title=Vanessa Williams Biography |accessdate=2015-09-15 |last= |first= |date= |publisher=biography.com }} In contrast, [[Hugh Hefner]] the publisher of ''[[Playboy]]'', was also given the opportunity to publish these photos but turned it down stating: "The single victim in all of this was the young woman herself, whose right to make this decision was taken away from her. If she wanted to make this kind of statement, that would be her business, but the statement wasn't made by her."{{cite web |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2015/09/vanessa-williams-nude-scandal-miss-america-judge |title=Vanessa Williams Makes Peace with Old Nude Scandal, Returns to Judge Miss America Pageant |accessdate=2015-09-14 |last=Robinson |first=Joanna |date=2015-09-05 |publisher=''Vanity Fair'' }} The black-and-white photos dated back to the summer of 1982 (after her freshman year at Syracuse University) when she worked as an assistant and makeup artist for [[Mount Kisco, New York]] photographer Tom Chiapel. At the time, Williams stated that Chiapel said that "he had a concept of having two models pose nude for silhouettes, basically to make different shapes and forms. The light would be behind the models. I was reluctant, but since he assured me that I would be the only one to see them and I would not be identifiable in the photographs, I agreed. He had also gotten another model to agree to this." In a 2012 interview with [[National Public Radio (United States)|NPR]], Williams discussed these events stating that her mother:
Kept saying, 'you're just like your father; you're too trusting' And there's a part of me that, I do give people the benefit of the doubt ... it's also being free ... that was the mode I was in at that particular time, when I took those racy pictures, because I was already in college so you can't tell me what to do. So - I wasn't actually in high school - so my mentality was what - I'm living my own life; I'm a spirited, young woman; I can handle this; I can handle anything. And at 19, you think you rule the world, and you can control things. And a lot of times, you don't.
After learning that ''Penthouse'' would be publishing these photos, the Miss America Organization responded by giving Williams 72 hours to resign. Williams later stated that "the heightened spectacle and circus of it all was kind of crazy. I had people saying 'Fight for the crown! Fight for the crown!' and people chanting 'Don't give it up! Don't secede!' " Williams also later noted that the situation was particularly hard on her mother Helen, who felt that she should not resign as Williams had performed her "duties and excelled at everything I was asked to do plus doing 50% more of appearances that were not scheduled because I was the first African American Miss America." Helen was also upset that "the pageant did not come to my support, they felt I needed to resign." Williams, however, decided to resign, and formally announced her decision at a press conference held on July 23, 1984. The title subsequently went to the first runner-up, Miss New Jersey [[Suzette Charles]] who served out the final seven weeks of Williams' reign.{{cite web |url=http://time.com/3961120/miss-america-scandal-vanessa-williams/ |title=The Scandal That Cost a Miss America Her Crown |accessdate=2015-09-16 |last=Latson |first=Jennifer |date=2015-07-23 |publisher= Time Magazine }}{{cite web |url=http://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/vanessa-williams-resigns-her-miss-america-title-july-23-news-photo/174528297 |title=Vanessa Williams Resigns |accessdate=2015-09-16 |last= |first= |date= |publisher=Getty Images }} On September 7, 1984, Williams filed a $500 million lawsuit against Chiapel and ''Penthouse'' publisher [[Bob Guccione]]; she dropped the lawsuit a year later stating that she wanted to put the scandal behind her.{{cite news|title=Ex-Miss America Vanessa Williams Overcomes Her Disgrace by Showing and Singing the Right Stuff|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20119453,00.html|date=January 30, 1989|first=John|last=Stark|first2=Michael|last2=Alexander|work=People|accessdate=September 25, 2011}}{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/08/nyregion/the-region-ex-miss-america-sues-over-photos.html | work=The New York Times | title=THE REGION; Ex-Miss America Sues Over Photos | date=September 8, 1984}} Ultimately, ''Penthouse'' published the unauthorized photos in its September 1984 issue, which the [[PBS]] documentary ''Miss America'' described as "the most successful issue ''Penthouse'' magazine ever printed, netting Guccione a windfall profit of $14 million." ==1984–2015== After her resignation, Williams rebounded as a recording artist and actress. However, she also faced a long period of what she would later describe as "[[Public humiliation|the betrayal, and the humiliation]], that happened to me on a grand scale."''[[Essence (magazine)|Essence]]'' magazine concurred stating that Williams was the subject of "[[Slut-shaming|public shaming and bullying]] from the public at large"{{cite web|url=http://www.essence.com/2015/09/10/vanessa-williams-judge-miss-america-pageant-32-years-after-scandal|title=Vanessa Williams Returns to Judge Miss America Pageant, 32 Years After Scandal|last=Lewis|first=Taylor|date=2015-09-10|publisher=''[[Essence (magazine)|Essence]]''|accessdate=2015-09-18}} and ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' noted that her "career and reputation tanked. Overnight, [Williams] went from being America's darling to a national disgrace."{{cite web|url=http://articles.philly.com/2014-02-11/entertainment/47204236_1_vanessa-williams-ramon-hervey-pageant|title=Long past that Miss A scandal, Vanessa Williams is happy she - and pageant - are back in Atlantic City|last=Armstrong|first=Jenice|date=2014-02-11|publisher=''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]''|accessdate=2015-09-15}} {{quote box|width=30%|align=right|quote='I had so much trouble being taken seriously not only because I was a beauty queen but a scandalous beauty queen on top of that,' she said, later adding in relation to Gershwin's reaction: 'Having that perception of me was when I realized what an obstacle I'd have.'|source=—Vanessa Williams in 2016}} She would also later state that these events delayed her career by about ten years,{{cite web |url=http://www.capecodtimes.com/article/20160712/ENTERTAINMENTLIFE/160719835 |title=Vanessa Williams explores school days and beyond |accessdate=2016-07-13 |last=Driscoll |first=Kathi |date=2016-07-12 |publisher=[[Cape Cod Times]] }} as "it seemed like an eternity in which I was the punch line to every late-night monologue ... [[Joan Rivers]], whom I adored and met on ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson#Joan Rivers|The Tonight Show]]'' during my reign, was particularly relentless. Just when I figured she'd exhausted every possible Vanessa Williams joke, she'd have a whole new slew of them." Williams would also later tell of one audition that she had during the late 1980s for a theatrical role. She was denied the role, however, because "the wife of lyricist [[Ira Gershwin]] decreed: 'Over my dead body will that whore be in my show.' " In addition, her parents experienced "an incredible amount of shame and humiliation" and were equally the subject of harassment at the time. Thirty years after the scandal broke, Amanda Marcotte suggested in ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' that
we owe a lot to Vanessa Williams for being a pioneer when it comes to showing the world how to recover when you've been unjustly shamed for being sexual. Williams could have slunk off into the shadows in shame, which no doubt many people at the time expected her to do. Williams picked herself up and kept fighting for a career as an entertainer, first by becoming a successful singer and then becoming a well-known comic actress ... Sleazy people tried to drag Vanessa Williams down with accusations of being sexual 30 years ago, but she moved on, showing she had nothing to be ashamed of.{{cite web |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/07/23/miss-america-hypocrisy-the-vanessa-williams-nude-photo-shaming.html |title=Miss America Hypocrisy: The Vanessa Williams Nude Photo Shaming |accessdate=2015-09-16 |last=Latson |first=Jennifer |date=2014-07-23 |publisher=''[[The Daily Beast]]'' }}
In addition, Williams commented on her ability to persevere after these events in a 2015 interview with ''[[Entertainment Tonight]]'' by stating that "you can't give up ... you always have to remember what you're made of and not let circumstances get in the way. They might delay your progress for the moment, but you always have to remember who you are, and that will give you the [[Eyes on the Prize|eyes on the prize]]."{{cite web |url=http://www.etonline.com/tv/176033_vanessa_williams_on_her_sexy_appearance_on_the_good_wife_it_starting_to_heat_up/ |title=Vanessa Williams on Her Sexy Appearance on 'The Good Wife': 'It's Starting to Heat Up' |accessdate=2014-11-14 |last=Chestang |first=Raphael |date=2014-11-13 |publisher=''[[Entertainment Tonight]]'' }} ==Miss America 2016== [[File:Oh How The Years Go By.JPG|thumb|275 px|a|right|Williams at the conclusion of her performance of "[[Oh How the Years Go By]]" at [[Miss America 2016]]]] Thirty-two years later, Williams returned to the Miss America stage on September 13, 2015, where she served as head judge for [[Miss America 2016]] and sang "[[Oh How the Years Go By]]."{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Nightline/video/vanessa-williams-returning-miss-america-scandal-33677692 |title=Vanessa Williams on Returning to Miss America After Scandal |accessdate=2015-09-11 |last=Roberts |first=Robin |date=2015-09-11 |publisher=ABC News }}{{cite web |url=http://www.etonline.com/news/171806_vanessa_williams_makes_triumphant_musical_return_to_miss_america_pageant/ |title=Vanessa Williams Makes Triumphant, Musical Return to Miss America Pageant |accessdate=2015-11-17 |last=Kile |first=Meredith |date=2015-09-13 |publisher=Entertainment Tonight }} After this performance, former Miss America CEO Sam Haskell issued a public apology to Williams, stating:
I have been a close friend of this beautiful and talented lady for 32 years. You have lived your life in grace and dignity, and never was it more evident than during the events of 1984, when you resigned. Though none of us currently in the organization were involved then, on behalf of today's organization, I want to apologize to you and to your mother, Miss Helen Williams. I want to apologize for anything that was said or done that made you feel any less the Miss America you are and the Miss America you always will be.{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/09/14/entertainment/miss-america-vanessa-williams-apology-feat/ |title=Vanessa Williams gets Miss America apology -- 32 years later |accessdate=2015-09-14 |last=Yan |first=Holly |date=2015-09-14 |publisher=[[CNN]] }}{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/15/arts/television/vanessa-williams-returns-to-miss-america-and-receives-an-apology.html?_r=0 |title=Vanessa Williams Returns to Miss America and Receives an Apology |accessdate=2015-09-14 |last=Rogers |first=Katie |date=2015-09-14 |publisher=''New York Times'' }}{{cite web |url=http://www.essence.com/2015/09/14/vanessa-williams-gets-apology-miss-america-32-years-later |title=Vanessa Williams Gets An Apology from Miss America, 32 Years Later |accessdate=2015-10-25 |last=Brammer |first=Imani |date=2015-09-14 |publisher=''[[Essence (magazine)|Essence]]'' }}
Williams responded by stating that she did the "best that I could, in my reign as Miss America, from 1983 to 1984." A few months after the pageant, Williams discussed the apology in an interview with [[Gayle King]], [[Charlie Rose]], and [[Norah O'Donnell]] for ''[[CBS This Morning]]''. King asked her about the circumstances that led to it stating, "I think many people were touched when the Miss America pageant issued an apology to you."{{cite web |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/videos/vanessa-williams-on-miss-america-apology-the-good-wife/ |title=Vanessa Williams on Miss America apology, "The Good Wife" |accessdate=2015-11-13 |last= |first= |date=2015-11-12 |publisher= ''[[CBS This Morning]]'' }} Williams credited Haskell (who was one of her judges during the Miss America 1984 pageant) for orchestrating her return. While both she and her mother initially responded with hesitation to the invitation, Williams finally agreed to participate on the condition that she could sing her song "Oh How the Years Go By" (to symbolize the passing of time since she was Miss America). She didn't know what Haskel would say, stating that she was simply told to stand and wait for him during the commercial break that would take place after her song. It was only when he arrived and placed his hand on her back (where she noticed that his hand was shaking) that Williams realized something significant was about to happen. Williams said that one of the most important outcomes of the apology was the positive impact that it had on her mother, who "endured a lot" during that period. After the pageant, Williams' replacement [[Suzette Charles]] stated in an interview with ''[[Inside Edition]]'' that she was perplexed over the apology and suggested that it was given for the purpose of ratings.{{cite web |url=http://www.insideedition.com/headlines/11900-beauty-queen-who-won-vanessa-williams-crown-miss-america-apology-was-about-ratings |title=Beauty Queen Who Won Vanessa Williams' Crown: Miss America Apology Was About Ratings |accessdate=2015-09-18 |last=Inside Edition |first= |date=2015-09-14 |publisher=Inside Edition }} Williams had previously commented on the events surrounding her return, stating in an interview with [[Robin Roberts (newscaster)|Robin Roberts]] that "there's a lot of people who feel I should return, so the people who harbor the resentment I understand it but realize that all of those people that were part of the old guard are no longer there." In the same interview, Roberts mentioned to Williams that in the present day (c. 2015), "people now release [similar] things to make a career."{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/09/14/entertainment/vanessa-williams-nude-photos-feat/ |title=Vanessa Williams and the declining scandal of nude photos |accessdate=2015-10-02 |last=France |first=Lisa |date=2015-09-14 |publisher=CNN }} Williams responded: "That's crazy. To think that oh you can look at a scandal and think that that would be good for your career, where for me it took every ounce of credibility and talent that I had and wiped it out." ==Further reading== ===Articles=== *"Vanessa Williams: New Miss America (cover story)." ''[[Jet (magazine)|Jet]]'', October 10, 1983. *"Here She is: Beautiful, brainy, and black, Vanessa Williams is by no means your ordinary beauty queen." ''[[Ebony (magazine)|Ebony]]'', December 1983: 132-136. *"Ex- Miss America Endures Pain, Embarrassment Sparked by Flap Over Nude Pictures." ''[[Jet (magazine)|Jet]]'', August 6, 1984: 60-62. *"Letters to the Editor: Miss America." ''[[Ebony (magazine)|Ebony]]'', October, 1984. ===Books=== * [[Katherine Shindle|Shindle, Kate]] ([[Miss America 1998]]). ''Being Miss America: Behind the Rhinestone Curtain.'' [[University of Texas Press]], 2014. *Wiliams, Vanessa and Helen Williams. ''You Have No Idea: A Famous Daughter, Her No-nonsense Mother, and How They Survived Pageants, Hollywood, Love, Loss (and Each Other).'' New York: [[Penguin Group|Gotham/Penguin Group]], 2012. ==Notes== {{reflist|3}} ==External links== *Shin, Annys. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/magazine/in-1983-vanessa-williams-became-the-first-black-miss-america/2017/09/11/9b99a4fe-81d0-11e7-ab27-1a21a8e006ab_story.html In 1983, Vanessa Williams became the first black Miss America], ''Washington Post,'' September 14, 2017. *"[http://www.reagan.utexas.edu/archives/photographs/large/C17523-23A.jpg President Reagan and Nancy Reagan talking with Vanessa Williams during a state dinner for President Karl Carstens of the Federal Republic of Germany in the cross hall]." October 4, 1983 - [[Ronald Reagan Presidential Library]] ===Video clips=== '''Miss America 2016''' *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wdGyU0GmfaI Vanessa Williams Sings Oh How the Years Go By] - [[Miss America 2016]], September 13, 2015 ("[[Oh How the Years Go By]]") *[http://www.tmz.com/videos/0_5mpuxlav/ Miss America CEO Sam Haskell Apologizes to Vanessa Williams] - [[Miss America 2016]], September 13, 2015 *[http://abcnews.go.com/WNT/video/vanessa-williams-mother-receive-apology-miss-america-organization-33758808 Vanessa Williams and Her Mother Receive an Apology From Miss America Organization] - [[ABC News]], September 14, 2015. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8fz7MlDeYBo&spfreload=5 Vanessa Williams | Real Biz with Rebecca Jarvis | ABC News] - [[ABC News]], April 27, 2016. '''Post-Miss America 1984''' * "[http://www.oprah.com/own-master-class/How-Vanessa-Williams-Endured-Her-Miss-America-Scandal-Video How Vanessa Williams Endured Her Miss America Scandal]" - [[Oprah's Master Class#Season Four .282014.29|Oprah's Master Class, Season 4, Episode 7]], July 13, 2014. *"[http://www.oprah.com/own-master-class/Vanessa-Williams-on-Becoming-the-First-Black-Miss-America-Video Vanessa Williams Reflects on Becoming the First Black Miss America] – [[Oprah's Master Class#Season Four .282014.29|Oprah's Master Class, Season 4, Episode 7]], July 13, 2014. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rc9L6O6yFNk Vanessa Williams at 25 - Singing her way up the pop chart] - Journalist Marcus Jones 1988 interview '''July 1984 resignation speech''' *[http://www.gettyimages.com/detail/video/at-a-press-conference-in-new-york-vanessa-williams-news-footage/455598352 Prep prior to and beginning of Vanessa William's Miss America resignation speech] - [[Getty Images]] video, July 23, 1984. *[http://www.gettyimages.com/detail/video/at-a-press-conference-in-new-york-vanessa-williams-news-footage/455598354 First half of Vanessa William's Miss America resignation speech] - [[Getty Images]] video, July 23, 1984. *[http://www.gettyimages.com/detail/video/at-a-press-conference-in-new-york-vanessa-williams-news-footage/455598350 Second half of Vanessa William's Miss America resignation speech] - [[Getty Images]] video, July 23, 1984. '''Miss America 1984''' *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=apUT1_BSr7I Vanessa Williams crowned Miss America 1984] - [[Miss America 1984]], September 17, 1983 *[http://greginhollywood.com/see-vanessa-williams-triumphant-miss-america-return-and-relive-her-1983-talent-competition-win-119633 Vanessa Williams performs "Happy Days Are Here Again,"] - [[Miss America 1984]], September 17, 1983. *"[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5a7L7QIHyIU Miss America 1984 Vanessa Williams Interview with Bill Boggs]" - [[Bill Boggs]] 1983 interview {{s-start}} {{s-ach}} {{succession box | before=[[Debra Maffett]] | title=[[Miss America]] | years=1984 | after=[[Suzette Charles]] }} {{succession box | before=Eileen Clark | title=[[Miss New York]] | years=1983 | after=Melissa Manning }} {{s-end}} {{Vanessa Williams}} {{MissAmericas 1980–1999}} {{New York pageant winners}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Williams, Vanessa}} [[Category:Vanessa Williams]] [[Category:Miss America]] [[Category:Miss America 1980s delegates]] [[Category:Miss America Preliminary Talent winners]] [[Category:Miss America winners]] [[Category:Miss New York winners]] [[Category:1984 controversies]] [[Category:History of racism in the United States]] [[Category:African-American history]] [[Category:Anti-black racism in the United States]] [[Category:Beauty pageant controversies]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox recurring event | name = Vectren Dayton Air Show | image = Dayton Air Show 2009.jpg | caption = Thunderbirds at the 2009 Dayton Air Show | status = | genre = [[Air show]] | dates = July (Since 2013, late June) | frequency = Annually | venue = [[Dayton International Airport]] | location = [[Vandalia, Ohio]] | coordinates = | country = United States | established = | attendance = 80,000 (2010) | activity = Static displays
Aerobatic displays | organized = | website = [http://www.daytonairshow.com// www.daytonairshow.com] }} The '''Vectren Dayton Air Show''' is an annual event held at the [[Dayton International Airport]] in [[Vandalia, Ohio]], eight miles north of [[Dayton, Ohio]]. The show takes place on a weekend in mid-July each year, but as of 2013, late June. The history of this flight exhibition dates back to 1910 and the [[Wright Company]]. {{cite web | title =Dayton Air Show viewed from the camera's eye | work = | publisher =Wilmington News Journal | date =2008-02-26 | url =http://www.wnewsj.com/main.asp?SectionID=49&SubSectionID=156&ArticleID=163440&TM=29812.26 | doi = | access-date = 2008-03-16 }} Dayton is the hometown of the [[Wright brothers]] and is where Orville and Wilbur built their first powered plane. {{cite web | title =Dayton Air Show; Dayton International Airport, July 29 - 30, 2006 | work = EVENT NEWS | publisher =NASA | year =2006 | url =http://www.nasa.gov/centers/glenn/events/Dayton_Air_Show.html | doi = | access-date = 2008-03-16 }} The show's main sponsor is [[Vectren|Vectren Corporation]] and it is considered to be one of the country’s premier aviation events. It is estimated that the 2010 Dayton Air Show attracted nearly 80,000 people and had a $5 million impact on the Dayton region's local economy.{{cite news | url=http://dayton.bizjournals.com/dayton/stories/2010/10/11/daily4.html?surround=lfn|title=Dayton Air Show annual facts|access-date=2010-10-11 | date=2010-10-11}} The 2012 show is estimated to have a $3 million impact on Dayton's economy. ==Performers and performances== The Dayton Air Show showcases some of the world's best known civilian and military pilots. One of which includes the [[Blue Angels]](Manning:2007) Other notable yearly performances include: the [[U.S. Air Force Thunderbirds]], [[U.S. Army Golden Knights]], [[Sean D. Tucker]], [[Patty Wagstaff]], and others.{{cite web|url=http://www.daytonairshow.com/pages/02_performers/featuredPerformers.html|title=Performers|access-date=2009-07-18|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130120075716/http://www.daytonairshow.com/pages/02_performers/featuredPerformers.html|archive-date=2013-01-20|dead-url=yes|df=}} Included with these are also various fly-overs by aircraft such as the [[F-18 Super Hornet]], [[B-2 Spirit]], [[B-52 Stratofortress]], [[A-10 Thunderbolt]], [[P-51 Mustang]], [[C-5 Galaxy]], and more. Along with performances, there are also more than 100 ground aircraft on display.{{cite web|url=http://www.daytonairshow.com/pages/02_performers/staticAircraft.html|title=Static aircraft|access-date=2009-07-18|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130121235230/http://www.daytonairshow.com/pages/02_performers/staticAircraft.html|archive-date=2013-01-21|dead-url=yes|df=}} The following is a list of all aircraft that have performed in the Dayton Air Show in 2009 and 2010. Please note that only the acts are listed, not static displays or other ground attractions. '''2011'''* (performances as of 1/20/11) * [[U.S. Air Force Thunderbirds]] * [[Sean D. Tucker]] * [[B-2 Bomber]] Flyover * [[Rockwell B-1 Lancer]] Flyover * Red Bull Helicopter * [[United States Army Parachute Team|Golden Knights]] * Tombstone Riders Wingwalking * Red Bull Air Force * [[A-10 Thunderbolt II]] * [[C-17 Globemaster III]] * School Time Jet Bus * [[Melissa Pemberton]] * [[UH-1H|UH-1H “Huey” Helicopter Rides]] * [[AH-1F|AH-1F Cobra Helicopter Rides]] '''2010'''{{cite web|url=http://www.usats.org/pages/02_performers/featuredPerformers.html|title= 2010 Performers and Performances|access-date=2010-10-11}} * [[U.S. Navy Blue Angels]] * USMC "Fat Albert" ([[C-130 Hercules]]) * [[Sean D. Tucker]] * [[F/A-18F Super Hornet]] * [[F-16 Fighting Falcon]] * [[C-17 Globemaster III]] * [[AreoShell Acobatic Team]] * [[B-17 bomber]] with pyrotechnics * [[P-51D Mustang]] * [[Douglas A-1 Skyraider]] * Team Fastrax Skydiving Team * School Time Jet Bus * Greg Poe * Pirated Skies – Kyle and Amanda Franklin * [[DC-3]] * [[UH-1H|UH-1H “Huey” Helicopter Rides]] * [[AH-1F|AH-1F Cobra Helicopter Rides]] '''2009'''{{cite web|url=http://www.daytonairshow.com/2009/pages/02_performers/featuredPerformers.html|title= 2009 Performers and Performances|access-date=2010-10-11}} [[File:Dayton Air Show 2009 C-17.jpeg|thumb|right|C-17 fly-over at 2009 Dayton Air Show]] * [[U.S. Air Force Thunderbirds]] * Brazilian Air Force Smoke Squadron * [[A-10 Thunderbolt II]] * [[F-18 Super Hornet]] * [[B-2 Spirit]] * [[B-52 Stratofortress]] * [[Boeing AH-64 Apache]] * [[F4U-4B Corsair]] * [[P-51D Mustang]] * [[United States Army Parachute Team|Golden Knights]] * [[Sean D. Tucker]] * [[Patty Wagstaff]] * [[UH-1H|UH-1H “Huey” Helicopter Rides]] * [[C-17 Globemaster III]] '''2008''' * [[F-22 Raptor]] * [[F-16 Fighting Falcon]] * [[F/A-18F Super Hornet]] * [[C-17 Globemaster III]] * [[C-130 Hercules]] * [[C-5 Galaxy]] * [[Boeing AH-64 Apache]] * [[F4U-4B Corsair]] * [[P-51D Mustang]] * [[B-25 Mitchell]] * [[AreoShell Acobatic Team]] * [[Sean D. Tucker]] * [[The Starfighters]] * [[Bill Stein]] * [[Shockwave Jet Truck]] '''2007''' * [[U.S. Air Force Thunderbirds]] * [[Brazilian Air Force Smoke Squadron]] * [[F/A-18 Hornet]] * [[Harrier AV-8B]] * [[B-1 Lancer]] * [[F-117 Nighthawk]] * [[F-4 Phantom]] * [[F-15 Eagle]] * [[Bell-Boeing V-22 Osprey]] * [[P-51 Mustang]] * [[F4U-4B Corsair]] * [[Jim LeRoy]] * [[Skip Stewart]] * [[Walt Pierce (pilot)|Walt Pierce]] * [[Double Trouble Wingwalking]] * [[Shockwave Jet Truck]] ==US Air, Trade & Technology Conference and Exposition== The US Air Trade and Technology Conference and Exposition (USATT) was initiated by Congressman [[Mike Turner]] to bring together [[General contractor|contractors]], [[subcontractor]]s, governments, and others to discuss issues pertaining to the [[Aerospace manufacturer|aerospace industry]].{{cite web | url=http://www.daytonairshow.com/pages/02_performers/default.html#1|title=USATT|access-date=2009-07-18}} The program focuses on [[Unmanned aerial vehicle|UAVs]], human performance, [[sensor]]s, and [[alternative fuel]]s, among other things.{{cite web | url=http://www.daytonairshow.com/pages/02_performers/default.html#1|title=USATT 2|access-date=2009-07-18}} Although the (USATT) takes place during the Dayton Air Show, it is not open to the public. ==Accidents and fatalities== An accident during a stunt flight resulted in the death of [[Jim LeRoy]], who was pronounced dead on July 28, 2007 in a military [[Medical evacuation|MEDEVAC]] helicopter while in transit to [[Miami Valley Hospital]] in [[Dayton, Ohio]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.whiotv.com/news/13774845/detail.html |title=Dayton Air Show Crash Kills Pilot - News Story - WHIO Dayton |access-date=2008-12-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201231032/http://www.whiotv.com/news/13774845/detail.html |archive-date=2008-12-01 |dead-url=yes |df= }}[http://www.airliners.net/discussions/general_aviation/read.main/3533213/ Jim LeRoy Dies In Airshow Crash — Civil Aviation Forum | Airliners.net]{{Cite web |url=http://www.whiotv.com/news/13780478/detail.html |title=Coroner: Pilot Died Instantly - News Story - WHIO Dayton |access-date=2008-02-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080222180158/http://www.whiotv.com/news/13780478/detail.html |archive-date=2008-02-22 |dead-url=yes |df= }} The reason of this crash was reported as pilot error by the [[NTSB]].{{cite web |last = Nolan |first = John |authorlink = |coauthors = |title = Federal inquiry cites pilot error in fatal Dayton Air Show crash |work = |publisher = airportbusiness.com |date = June 20, 2008 |url = http://www.airportbusiness.com/online/article.jsp?siteSection=1&id=20661 |doi = |access-date = 2008-06-20 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110707100453/http://www.airportbusiness.com/online/article.jsp?siteSection=1&id=20661 |archive-date = July 7, 2011 |dead-url = yes |df = mdy-all }} On June 22, 2013, a plane carrying wing walker Jane Wicker crashed at the air show, killing both Wicker and pilot Charlie Schwenker.{{cite news|title=Plane with wing walker crashes at Ohio air show, kills 2|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/06/22/plane-with-wing-walker-crashes-at-ohio-air-show/2448941/|publisher=USA Today|access-date=22 June 2013|first1=Alan|last1=Gomez|date=2013-06-22}} On June 23, 2017, the day before the air show, a Thunderbirds [[General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon|F-16D]] jet, not scheduled to perform, was taxiing to a staging area after a familiarization flight, when witnesses reported a gust of wind flipped the aircraft onto its top in a grassy area next to the taxiway. Both the pilot and a team crew member were trapped in the airplane for two hours; the pilot suffered only minor injuries while the crew member had no visible injuries. The Thunderbirds canceled their scheduled performances for both days of the air show.{{ cite news | url = http://www.dayton.com/news/national/thunderbird-plane-flips-its-top-ohio-air-show/7UcEitelzbTiO2Rv48vE1I/ | title = Thunderbird F-16 plane flips on its top at Ohio air show | newspaper = [[Dayton Daily News]] | author = Staff | date = June 23, 2017 | access-date = June 24, 2017 }}{{ cite news | url = http://www.daytondailynews.com/news/local/thunderbirds-jet-ohio-accident-good-condition/bAdEgFcbwLtNrTPgDWyPOM/ | title = 2 on Thunderbirds jet in Ohio accident in good condition | newspaper = [[Dayton Daily News]] | author = [[Associated Press]] | date = June 23, 2017 | access-date = June 24, 2017 }}{{ cite news | url = http://www.daytondailynews.com/news/thunderbirds-will-not-perform-sunday-vectren-dayton-air-show/9hYLy25uRDPep71YW9P2HJ/ | title = Thunderbirds will not perform Sunday at Vectren Dayton Air Show | newspaper = [[Dayton Daily News]] | author1 = Breaking news staff | last2 = Barber | first2 = Barrie | last3 = Driscoll | first3 = Kara | date = June 24, 2017 | access-date = June 24, 2017 }} ==Effect of weather on attendance== Unusually high temperatures led to greatly decreased attendance for the 2012 show. As such, it was announced in October, 2012 that the 2013 show would be moved from July to June.{{cite news | title=Dayton Air Show moved to June | last=Barber | first=Barrie | publisher=[[Dayton Daily News]] | date = October 11, 2012 | url=http://www.daytondailynews.com/news/business/dayton-air-show-moving-to-june/nSYzx/ | access-date=October 12, 2012}} The trend has continued through 2016; the 2016 show was held from June 18-19 2016. The previous year's air show had lost attendance as well due to weather, however, the loss was due to heavy rains, which also forced the temporary grounding of some acts.{{Cite news|url=http://www.daytondailynews.com/news/news/local/blue-angels-and-wwii-act-headline-2016-air-show/nnb6Z/|title=Blue Angels and WWII act headline 2016 air show|first=Barrie|last=Barber|date=September 10, 2015|access-date=June 3, 2016|publisher=Dayton Daily News}} An estimated 51,000 spectators attended the 2016 show, a large increase from the 40,000 of the previous year. This was despite the absence of a scheduled headliner act, the [[Blue Angels]], following the group's temporary grounding due to the death of one of its pilots in a crash on June 2.{{Cite news|url=http://www.whio.com/news/news/local/dayton-air-show-brings-in-estimated-51k-people/nrjhP/|title=Dayton Air Show brings in estimated 51K people|first=Barrie|last=Barber|date=June 20, 2016|access-date=June 20, 2016|publisher=WHIO-TV}} ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} ==References== *{{cite book | last =Manning | first =William | title =Cincinnati, OH: A Photographic Portrait | publisher =Twin Lights Publishers | year =2007 | location = | pages =128 pages | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=0Ruo1mTgcHAC&pg=PA109&dq=%22Dayton+Air+Show%22+site:gov&as_brr=1&sig=aH71sxIMmaMs6lnz8LyYpIM54zk | doi = | isbn = 1-885435-73-8 }} ==External links== {{wikinews|Deadly crash at Dayton, Ohio air show}} {{Commons category|Dayton Air Show}} * [http://www.daytonairshow.com/ Dayton Air Show] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110728145805/http://www.usattexpo.org/9OH/index.asp (USATT) Website] {{International airshows}} [[Category:Air shows in the United States]] [[Category:Aviation accidents and incidents at air shows]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Montgomery County, Ohio]] [[Category:Culture of Dayton, Ohio]] [[Category:Annual events in Ohio]] [[Category:Aviation in Ohio]]
